course_title: People on the Move: Migration, Globalisation and Livelihood
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. CA Wilcock', 'dr. HM Hintjens', 'dr. KA Siegmann', 'dr. KE Grabska', 'dr. M Meskoub']

course_title: People on the Move: Migration, Globalization and Livelihoods
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. HM Hintjens', 'dr. KA Siegmann', 'dr. M Meskoub', 'prof.dr. D Gasper']
text:
Inhoud Course description
This course locates the dynamics of migration in a historical perspective, paying attention to the geo-political and economic contexts and taking note of the evolving complexity and multi-causal nature of migration. The course deals with the causes of migration (for example, demand for labour, displacement, differences in income and employment opportunities between two regions); and its consequences (e.g., ‘brain/skill drain’, remittance of money by migrant, gender balance at origin and destination); as well as the cultural and political dimensions of migration such as the debate on the control of migration and integration of migrants.
Modern migratory movement can best be understood in the context of a globalized market economy that directs and regulates the flows of goods, money and labour. As far as migration is concerned the impact of globalization goes far beyond the international movement of labour. The course pays particular attention to the formation of diverse migratory regimes within and across countries and regions.
Globalization has accelerated the pace of liberalization, deregulation and flexibilisation of labour markets.
Labour, unlike other goods and commodities, is embodied in human beings, with physical, gendered and cultural characteristics that are shaped by history. This gives labour migration its distinct political and cultural dimensions. The course will also deal with some of these aspects of migration by addressing the current debate in receiving countries in Europe and USA with regard to the integration of migrants.
Besides labour migration, there are other migratory flows such as family re-union, migration for education and most important of all forced migration from regions and countries in situations of conflict or war.  We consider how forced migration is ‘managed’ and how it is being redefined, legally and politically, and in relation to international agreements and treaties such as 1951 Geneva Refugee Convention.  We also ask questions on how internally displaced persons are affected by migration-/refugee-regimes and regulations, and how state and non-state actors in various parts of the globe seek to manage and control ‘forced migration’ in relation to restrictions on ‘other’ migration.
  Leerdoelen Learning objectives
This is a course on the political economy of migration and mobility in the world. It provides participants with knowledge of the causes, character and consequences of national/internal and international migratory movements in the world. Those Specialising in Population and Development are required to take ISS-EGSH-0057 as part of their Specialisation programme.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Course Description
Every professional need certain skills. In our Master, we offer a unique personal skills development trajectory. In this trajectory, you create your own learning process by setting your learnings goals and creating your Portfolio. To offer you a complete program, The Personal Development Trajectory consists of three sections: group lectures, individual skills development and a career course.

First, this trajectory offers plenary skills trainings, with a focus on communication. These interactive workshops create a basis for skills and actions you have to take during the core courses. The interactive workshops consist of two components: they combine a lecture with an experiential event. The lecture part provides you theoretically with techniques and methods to handle certain situations. On the other hand, the experiential event gives you the possibility to practice these techniques yourself, so that you will become familiar with these skills. There are four workshops with the following topics:

 
  • Goal-Setting and being a Force for Positive Change
  • Verbal & non-verbal communication, Feedback, interviewing skills, and open & closed questions
  • Working in Teams
  • Presentation Skills
 
Furthermore, you will develop yourself on the individual level. During the individual part of the Personal Development Trajectory, you focus on your individual development. What do you want to develop? What appeals to you? In Canvas, you will create your own Portfolio. By the hand of Portfolio assignments, you formulate your own learning goals for each course. Then, after each core course, you reflect on what you have learned. Creating the Portfolio gives you access to the rest of this trajectory and is therefore obligatory. The Portfolio Assignments will be graded with a “Pass” or “Fail”.  

Moreover, aside from working on your team assignments for the core courses, you are also asked to meet up with your teams to provide peer feedback to one another. You do this on three occasions:
 
  1. After the first week of each course, you meet up with your team to discuss what your individual goals are for the coming block, and what you want to achieve in the current course.
  2. Halfway during the block, you meet with your team to provide each other peer feedback. You do this by using the statements “I like ...” and “I wish …” in which each team member receives feedback from their peers concerning what they liked about them during the first few weeks, and what improvements or changes they would wish to see.
  3. This process is repeated at the end of a block, in which the teams also discuss the improvements made based on the first peer feedback session.
 
For each of these three meetings you are asked to write a short memo for your portfolio, in which you describe what you got out of it.

Next to creating your Portfolio, you have the possibility  to schedule two individual coaching sessions with Marja Flory. These meetings function as a reflection on your personal development. Here, you can discuss things such as your own learning goals, the peer feedback that has been received, and so on. Make sure you meet Ms. Dr. Flory well-prepared, so you can get the most out of this coaching session. Remember, you are in charge of your own development! Lastly, the individual part of this trajectory also consists of one assignment, see the header “Assessment” below.

Your Future Career
The final aspect of the Personal Development Trajectory is Your Future Career (YFC), which consists of several modules that are offered on nearly all of the RSM masters. This is a separate course within the PDT, and accounts for 1 ECTs. The course has its own page on Canvas and is fully coordinated by the Career Center to help you prepare for the time you are going to find a job.
Leerdoelen
Intended Learning Outcomes
After completing this course, you will be capable of the following:
  • Reflecting on his/her personal learning goal(s)
  • Understanding communication processes
  • Giving and receiving proper and constructive feedback
  • Applying interview techniques
  • Applying presentation techniques

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The course consists of 4 different parts.  However, due to the nature of the content, these 4 parts do not correlate perfectly with the 4 lectures and the assignments.  

Part 1: Interview strategy, your story, your aspirations
During the 1st lecture, we will fast forward all the way to the end and describe both what an interview strategy looks like and explore one of its key components: how to tell your story.  In the associated homework assignment, you will reflect on your motivations, strengths and personality traits to try & articulate a possible career direction - all of which should be the basis for the other part of the assignment: a first draft of your story.  

Part 2: Tell me about a time when...
In the 2nd lecture, we will explore how to recount in story-like manner your meaningful personal and professional experiences.  In the associated 2nd and 3rd assignments you will develop a portfolio of powerful stories that you can recount as you navigate through your job search and the recruitment process.  

Part 3: Networking
In the 3rd lecture, we will explore various high impact tools to help you build your network by connect with unknown people eager to help.  You will learn how to reach out and how to conduct impactful conversations with them so that you can get advice from them and learn about the market and opportunities.  In the associated assignment you will conduct a conversation with one such person and report back on your findings and experience.

Part 4: Interview strategy (continued)
In final, lecture, we will complete our exploration of interview strategies.  In particular, you will learn about the non-story aspects of job interviews. In the associated assignment you will develop an interview strategy for a potential interview with one of your target employers.

Attendance
Although course attendance is not compulsory, it is strongly recommended for ALL lectures.  Satisfactory completion of the Assignments will require a detailed understanding of concepts that will be discussed during class and that the materials alone cannot cover.  Out of respect for your fellow classmates and faculty, plan to attend sessions in full from beginning to end: joining late and leaving early are not acceptable options.
 
Resit possibilities
Since the course is pass/fail and there are multiple opportunities to earn credit beyond the minimum, there will not be an opportunity to resit any individual assignment or the course as a whole.
  Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
What would you say if you could approach the job search process with clarity of purpose, confidence and knowing both how to secure interviews and thrive in them?  The overall objective of this course is to provide you cutting-edge tools and methodologies to:
 
  1. Find out what makes you uniquely attractive as a job candidate
  2. Decide what you want to do
  3. Build a network of people eager to help you
  4. Learn about the less visible job opportunities
  5. Secure job interviews
  6. Pass interviews
 
By the end of this course you will be able to:
  • Identify your career-relevant strengths, traits, values and motivations
  • Build and engage professional networks to obtain advice and identify career opportunities
  • Use the art of storytelling to talk about yourself, your past experiences and your professional aspirations in multiple recruiting contexts such as networking and job interviews
  • Develop job interview strategies and execute them

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. M Littel', 'dr. MAE Marissen', 'dr. RER Van der Hallen']
text:
Inhoud In dit blok staan persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en identiteitsstoornissen centraal. Er zal eerst gekeken worden naar het onderscheid tussen normale persoonlijkheidstrekken en persoonlijkheidsstoornissen. Persoonlijkheidsstoornissen vormen een aparte as binnen de DSM-V en kunnen worden onderverdeeld in drie clusters. Cluster A bestaat uit de paranoïde, schizoïde en schizotypische persoonlijkheidsstoornis. Cluster B omvat de antisociale, de borderline, de theatrale en narcistische persoonlijkheidsstoornis. Tot cluster C worden de ontwijkende of vermijdende, de afhankelijke, de obsessief-compulsieve of dwangmatige persoonlijkheidsstoornis gerekend. In dit blok zal dieper worden ingegaan op het klinisch beeld, de diagnostiek en de behandeling van bovengenoemde stoornissen. Daarnaast zal in dit blok ook aandacht worden besteed aan de rol die identiteit speelt bij persoonlijkheidsstoornissen. Tevens zullen de dissociatieve stoornissen en genderidentiteitsstoornissen aan bod komen. Tot slot zal er middels een opdracht ook aandacht worden besteed aan impulscontrole stoornissen. Ook hierbij staan wederom het klinisch beeld, de diagnostiek, de behandeling en actuele theoretische inzichten centraal.
 
Blokopdrachten persoonlijkheidsdiagnostiek
In dit blok wordt door middel van twee opdrachten dieper ingegaan op relevante onderwerpen. Ten eerste zal middels een blokopdracht aandacht worden besteed aan stoornissen binnen de impulscontrole. Tevens zal er middels een blokopdracht aandacht besteed worden aan zelfreflectie door middel van het invullen en interpreteren van de Young Schema Questionnaire (YSQ). Leerdoelen
Aan het eind van dit blok, heb je substantiële kennis van het klinisch beeld, de prevalentie, de etiologie, de diagnostiek en de behandeling van:
  • de paranoïde persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de schizoïde persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de schizotypische persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de antisociale persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de borderline persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de theatrale persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de narcistische persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de vermijdende persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de afhankelijke persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de obsessief-compulsieve persoonlijkheidsstoornis
  • de persoonlijkheidsstoornis niet anders omschreven
  • dissociatieve stoornissen
  • genderdysforie (voorheen de gender identiteitsstoornis)

Verder doe je veel kennis op over:
  • het onderscheid tussen persoonlijkheidstrekken en persoonlijkheidsstoornissen
  • thema’s zoals afweer, overdracht en tegenoverdracht binnen de behandeling
  • psychodiagnostische meetinstrumenten om persoonlijkheidsstoornissen vast te stellen
  • de mate waarin persoonlijkheidsstoornissen veranderd kunnen worden
  • verschillende therapievormen om persoonlijkheidsstoornissen te behandelen en hun effectiviteit
  • je eigen (dis)functionele schema’s en hoe deze jouw kijk als persoon en toekomstig therapeut op de wereld om je heen kunnen beïnvloeden

college: Erasmus University College
lecturers: ['dr. G Noordzij', 'LIS Giel, MSc', 'M Vaughan - Waalwijk, MSc']
text:
Inhoud The course Personality Psychology looks at the patterns of thoughts, feelings and behaviour that make a person unique but at the same time the description of a person in terms of similarity to others (i.e., central tendencies). The course deals with ‘normal’ personalities and the processes that define them. We concern ourselves with the different views and perspectives on personality and individual differences. The course is a ‘project-based’ course. For eight weeks you act as a consultant to investigate and respond to a challenging question in which ‘a real-world problem’ of a client could be answered by means from an individual differences perspective. This gives you the opportunity to work collaboratively and autonomously on the design of a project and the suggestion for a solution. The project concludes with an advice report for your client. Leerdoelen At the end of this course:
  • You can define and understand the overarching concepts of personality and individual differences;
  • You have an understanding of and are able to distinguish between the different perspectives on personality;
  • You can explain how key aspects of personality and individual differences contribute to understanding human behaviour;
  • You can apply scientific knowledge of a personality perspective such that you can analyse and solve a small real-world problem that is grounded in individual differences. This means:
    • You will have the basic skills to analyse and clarify a problem brought up by a client;
    • You are able to write a proposal for a client;
    • You can justify your choice of literature/theories and methodology;
    • You are able to apply literature/theories into practice to solve a small real-world problem;
    • You are able to write an advisory report for a client.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. K Breevaart', 'E van der Wal, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
Hoewel mensen in zeer veel opzichten van elkaar kunnen verschillen, zal dit blok met name gaan over verschillen in de persoonlijkheid van mensen. Het blok besteedt aandacht aan de belangrijkste invalshoeken, waaronder de psychoanalytische theorie, de leertheorie, humanistische theorieën en trekkentheorieën. Ook zal het blok stilstaan bij theorieën over intelligentie en over de rol van genetische en omgevingsfactoren die gedrag kunnen verklaren. Daarnaast zal het blok een inleiding geven in een aantal psychometrische basisbegrippen en het meten van individuele verschillen.
 
Leerdoelen Doel van dit blok is bekend te raken met de psychologische theorieën over persoonlijkheid en gedrag. Hoe zijn mensen geworden wie zij zijn? Wat is de rol van de opvoeding? Hoe stabiel en voorspelbaar is gedrag eigenlijk? Welke benaderingen zijn er om persoonlijkheid te meten? In dit blok zal de student proberen op deze en andere vragen een antwoord te vinden.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In dit blok richten we ons op de thematiek van personeelswerving, -selectie, classificatie en plaatsing. Theorieën en technieken komen aan bod voor het effectief passen van individuele behoeften, voorkeuren, kennis, capaciteiten en vaardigheden, met de behoeften en voorkeuren van de organisatie. We besteden onder meer aandacht aan voorspellings- en besluitvormingsmodellen tijdens selectie. Voorts gaan we in op utiliteitsmodellen, anti-discriminatiemodellen, klinische en statistische predictie, en validiteitsgeneralisatie. Onderwijsgroepsbijeenkomsten hebben de vorm van het maken van opdrachten die gerelateerd zijn aan bovenstaande thema’s nadat deze zijn behandeld tijdens college. Het bijwonen van de colleges is van cruciaal belang voor de onderwijsgroepen.
 
Leerdoelen Dit blok heeft tot doel de student een grondig inzicht te verschaffen in de theorie en praktijk van personeelselectie. Enerzijds is er een duidelijk accent op statistische modellen voor voorspelling en besluitvorming bij selectie en theorievorming over selectie. Anderzijds wordt er middels een practicum stilgestaan bij best practices op dit vlak door een goede worteling in de praktijk van selectie en socialisatie.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. M de Mul', 'dr. M Vollmann', 'dr. RA Scheepers', 'H Alla, MSc', 'I Kizil, MSc', 'JJA van de Rijt, MSc', 'LA Visser, MSc', 'MT van Kouwen, MA', 'S Tallouch']
text:
Inhoud Als professional in de zorgsector zet je je in voor anderen. Om dit op een betrokken en bewuste wijze te doen, is het van belang dat een student zichzelf goed kent. Met meer inzicht over jezelf, maak je ook professionele en persoonlijke keuzes die beter bij je passen. De Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn helpt een student te ontdekken hoe hij/zij zijn/haar (zelf)kennis het beste in de echte wereld kan toepassen en hoe de student, als uniek persoon, een verschil kan maken in de zorg. De lijn is gecentreerd rondom zeven kerncompetenties: studeren, projectmatig werken, samenwerken, communiceren, zelfinzicht, reflecteren en zelfsturend vermogen.
 
Onder begeleiding van een mentor worden met behulp van mentoraatsbijeenkomsten en thuisopdrachten verschillende onderwerpen en competenties behandeld. Middels het uploaden van opdrachten in verschillende vormen (voiceclip, filmpje, reflectie-opdrachten, etc.), bouwt de student een eigen ePortfolio op die in het teken staat van zijn/haar ontwikkeling.
  • Blok 1: Tijdens dit blok gaan studenten kijken naar hun drijfveren en waarden. Welke waarden zijn belangrijk en komen terug in keuzes die worden gemaakt? Aan de hand daarvan worden persoonlijke- en professionele doelen opgesteld. Ook wordt er aandacht besteed aan beroepsoriëntatie. Wat kan je nu eigenlijk worden na de studie? Waar zijn oud-studenten terecht gekomen? Kunnen zij inspireren? Ten slotte werken we aan culturele bewustwording van de student.
  • Blok 2: Het tweede blok staat in het teken van het duiden van persoonlijkheid. De student leert meer over zijn/haar eigen persoonlijkheid en hoe deze verschilt van anderen. De student reflecteert op hoe hij/zij handelt in bepaalde professionele situaties.
  • Blok 3: Samenwerken en projectmatig werken staan centraal in dit blok. Wat is jouw rol in een groep en hoe ga jij om met andere persoonlijkheden? Daarnaast wordt er aandacht besteed aan vaardigheden als vergaderen, het maken van een tijdsplanning en notuleren.
  • Blok 4: Het eerste jaar van de lijn wordt afgesloten met een eindopdracht waarmee wordt aangetoond dat er gewerkt is aan de opgestelde doelen uit het eerste blok.
 
De Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn zet zich voort in jaar 2 van de studie, waar de lijn een vrijer karakter heeft en de student (gedeeltelijk) zelf kan bepalen aan welke vaardigheden hij/zij wilt werken.
 
  Leerdoelen
Competentie Leerdoel
Studeren De student kent haar leervoorkeur o.b.v. de leerscan van Prof. Ruijter.
De student kan de sterke en zwakke kanten van haar leervoorkeur benoemen.
De student kent het beroepsperspectief dat ESHPM hem biedt.
Projectmatig werken De student kan een planning opstellen t.b.v. groepswerk.
De student kan een vergadering opstellen en notuleren.
Samenwerken De student kan mondelinge feedback geven en het toepassen.
De student kan in de groepsopdracht verschillende rollen aannemen (d.w.z. notulist of voorzitter).
De student kan constructief reflecteren op het groepsproces.
Communiceren De student kan een effectieve presentatie in het Nederlands houden.
Zelfinzicht De student kan zijn persoonlijkheid duiden o.b.v. het Enneagram.
De student kent zijn eigen culturele achtergrond en kan reflecteren op hoe dit zijn/haar vorming heeft beïnvloed.
Reflecteren De student kan persoonlijk reflecteren op de inzichten opgedaan tijdens het interview met een patiënt.
De student kan reflecteren op haar rol als onderzoeker.
Zelfsturend vermogen De student kan persoonlijke leerdoelen formuleren voor het eerste jaar van de studie.
De student kan, terugkijkend op het jaar, reflecteren op het eigen leerproces en SMART doelen stellen voor Bachelor 2.

lecturers: ['BS Jadoenath', 'dr. GE Berner', 'drs. NJ Smit', 'DW Dirks', 'FG Tedja', 'M Rieger', 'prof.dr. AS Bedi', 'prof.dr.ir. DJM Hilhorst', 'T Harte', 'VV Tchirikova']

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['AMM Peultier, MSc', 'CL Whichello, MSC MA', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'JJA van de Rijt, MSc', 'prof.dr. MPMH Rutten - van Molken', 'TA Kanters, PhD']
text:
Inhoud A pharmaceutical pricing strategy is more than simply setting a price to recover R&D investments and adding a mark-up to guarantee a desired profit level. Indeed, a price has often little to no relationship to manufacturing costs in this market. It is the perceived value of a new drug in a broad sense, and how a drug is positioned in the market, that is critical to its success. Especially now that development costs are growing, blockbusters are being displaced by niche drugs, treatment is increasingly personalized, and governments are limiting expenditure on healthcare. For a pharmaceutical company, getting sufficient returns on investments and keeping the pipeline filled becomes increasingly challenging.

Many pharmaceutical companies have shifted their focus from sales and marketing to strategic pricing and market access. This has been accompanied by a shift from a product-centered culture to a disease service-centered culture. Clinicians remain important decision makers, but they must move within the boundaries set by payers. Payers are now the ultimate and most influential clients of the pharmaceutical industry.

The course Pharmaceutical Pricing and Market Access (PPMA) aims to provide students with a detailed understanding of this complex and changing market. We will follow each step of the life cycle of a drug, from phase II clinical trials up to post-launch, integrating both market access theory and examples from the real world. We will discuss the importance of optimizing product launches, real world post marketing studies and innovative pricing agreements. Students will gain insight into how the latest changes in regulations, guidelines and stakeholders in the major EU, US and BRIC countries impact the success of brands, as well as the interactions between all the actors on the markets. They will learn to understand how differences between healthcare systems impact optimizing market access for pharmaceutical products.

Course structure
The course consists of:
  • 12 interactive lectures with plenary discussion (2 lectures of 3 hours each per week)
  • 6 small tutorial group meetings (2 hours, once per week) with 10 to 15 students using Problem Based Learning to formulate learning goals, exchange knowledge and have discussions about the case of the week
  • 2 meetings in which small groups of (around 3 to 4) students present a business case and debate about the presented market access strategies
Exam
The written examination is 80% of the final grade. The remainder derives from the two presentations on the business cases (i.e. 10% of the final grade for each case). Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.
The presentations of the business cases are scheduled in the third and sixth week and the students’ presence is obligated. The minimum grade for the weighted average of the written examination and the business cases is 5.5. There will be 1 re-sit of the written examination and no re-sits of the presentations. No reading materials and notes are allowed during the exam, other than an English dictionary. A calculator is allowed.

Re-sit
The re-sit is composed as one single written examination that comprises the entire course learning goals and thus counts for 100%.
  Leerdoelen By the end of the course students will:
  • Have insight in pharmaceutical cost and pricing trends and the drivers thereof;
  • Be able to reason how the life cycle of a drug is affected by different aspects of life cycle management;
  • Know how pricing and reimbursement systems of key international markets work;
  • Understand key concepts of pharmaceutical innovation, pricing and market access (e.g. value based pricing, price referencing, market access arrangements);
  • Be able to develop a pricing and market access strategy for drugs;
  • Understand how the market for medical devices differs from the drug-market.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['B.H.C. Stricker', 'dr. K.M.C. Verhamme', 'dr. S.M.J.M. Straus', "E.M. O'Neill"]

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text: Leerdoelen How can philosophers contribute to public policy? We will explore this question from theory and practice. In a first step we will discuss the role of philosophers in society and different ways of how philosophers can and should or should not contribute to public policy. In a second step, you will learn to apply your skills as a philosopher to public debates and public policy, with the guidance of policy advisor and philosopher Manuel Buitenhuis. After finishing this course, you will have (i) gained insights in applying philosophical skills to topics in public policy, (ii) acquired a deeper understanding of philosophical issues underlying a number of important policy areas, and (iii) have acquired important philosophical skills that are relevant for a position in policy, such as  to conduct policy-oriented research and develop research-based policy reports.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course Methodology of Management Science focused on the selection of appropriate research methods for the scientific analysis of managerial issues. This Philosophy of Science course not only addresses deeper philosophical questions of how scientific research as a human activity can track the truth about 'management reality', but also has the aim of providing a conceptual apparatus to understand and evaluate the assumptions and truth claims of the many different theories that exist in the field of management. Management is an interdisciplinary field, and therefore harbors different theories that explain management reality using different concepts and relying on very different assumptions. Sometimes theories in management even give incompatible accounts of the same phenomenon. For both researchers and future managers it is important to be able to make a reasoned choice between the theories that apply to a specific phenomenon. This course not only seeks to provide students with the conceptual apparatus that is relevant in choosing between different theoretical perspectives, but also aims to develop the critical abilities of students to analyse and evaluate theories in management. Leerdoelen The principal objective of this course is to equip students for evaluating and choosing between the many different theories in the field management.
Questions that will be addressed during the course include:
  • What is the difference between theories and concepts, on the one hand, and facts and empirical research on the other? - To what extent can and should theories in social science be based on facts and empirical research?
  • Should there be room for concepts and theories that do not reduce to facts and observations?
  • If we accept non-empirical concepts and theories in social science, how do we establish their validity?
  • What are the assumptions of theories in management, and to what extent are these assumptions scientifically acceptable?
  • Should we look only at behavior in social science, or do human intentions also matter in explaining social reality? - To what extent can social science be value free?
  • Can social science say something sensible about normative questions, or should social scientists remain silent about normative issues?

Skills
At the end of this course the student should have obtained the following skills:
  • analytical thinking;
  • argumentation;
  • theory choice;
  • philosophical underpinnings;
  • academic ethics.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud This course offers a brief history of science itself and of the philosophy of science, focusing on the styles of scientific reasoning in
- Ancient and Medieval Science
- The Scientific Revolution
- Romanticism and Positivism
- Classical Philosophy of Science
Students reflect critically on the powers and limits of the various styles of scientific reasoning. Leerdoelen
This course was previously titled Critical Creative Reasoning. If students already completed Critical Creative Reasoning, they are not expected to complete Philosophy of Science 1.

(1) The student has a basic acquaintance with the history of science, and is able to distinguish between and to situate historically six different styles of scientific reasoning.
(2) The student has a basic acquaintance with the history of the philosophy of science, and is able to distinguish between and to situate historically five different phases of the philosophy of science.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud The nature of science and scientific methods; analyzing core concepts of science (theory, model, confirmation, verification, infirmation, falsification, observation, explanation, experiment, evidence); introduction to philosophical debates concerning whether science tells us the truth about reality; social components of science; metaphysical presuppositions that make scientific inquiry possible; basic elements from logic and epistemology. In two tutor meetings, additional auxiliary lectures will be provided about logic and epistemology (specially intended for Double Degree students). Leerdoelen This course was previously titled General Philosophy of Science. If students already completed General Philosophy of Science, they don't have to complete Philosophy of Science 2.

(1) the student acquires the concepts, insights and skills that are involved in understanding philosophical texts about science.
(2) the student acquires the concepts, insights and skills that are involved in making exercises about philosophical texts to test the student’s understanding.
(3) the student acquires the concepts, insights and skills that are involved in writing a short philosophical text about science.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud Although ignorance is the engine of science, turning general, philosophical wonder into a specific, well-defined research problem, is a very complex, demanding skill, that one can and should actually acquire. Building on insights from the history and philosophy of science, this course discusses and illustrates several methods to define and re(de)fine research problems stepwise, and invites students to reflect critically and creatively about the prerequisites, the powers and the limits of problem solving in both their own discipline and in interdisciplinary contexts. Leerdoelen
This course was previously titled Analytic Metaphysics. If students already completed Analytic Metaphysics, they are not expected to complete Philosophy of Science 3.

(1) The student acquires the skill to define a research problem and to re(de)fine it stepwise. (2) The student reflects on how to improve problem solving within one’s own discipline. (3) The student experiences and reflects on the prerequisites and benefits of interdisciplinary problem solving.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud Individualism: methodological and ontological
Reduction and supervenience
Multiple realizability and laws
Reflexivity
Anchors and grounds
Constitutive rules
Anti-realism and infallibilism
  Leerdoelen The course aims at familiarizing students with the main issues discussed in contemporary philosophy of social science, with particular emphasis on social ontology. The students will learn to identify and distinguish the most prominent positions in debates concerning individualism, reductionism, grounding, constitution, and realism. They will also analyse and critically assess the main arguments brought in favour and against each position, with the aim of identifying the ways in which these debates may be resolved.

course_title: Planning for Social and Economic Growth
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud The course will teach the students the basics of plant biology, including plant structure and morphology, metabolism, reproduction, genetics, evolution and systematics. Main goal of this course is to remove all vestiges of zoocentrism from the students’ mindsets, giving them the tools to appreciate the uniqueness and specificities of the Plant Kingdom. The students will be able to distinguish the plants from other life forms, to understand how a plant is structured and which modifications have evolved to cope with the different terrestrial environments, to describe the different parts composing a plant by using appropriate botanical terms, to discover why plants are the life sources for food and oxygen for all organisms on Earth, to understand the significance of the diplobiontic life cycle of plants, and to appreciate the intricate biochemical and signalling networks of plants including those of photosynthesis, cell respiration, and hormone action. Finally, the students will appreciate the richness of plant diversity resulting from eons of evolution, and to enter a natural area and distinguish the plants encountered as being either Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms or Angiosperms.
Leerdoelen
After completing this course, the students will:
  • Be acquainted with the anatomy and the morphology of the different plant organs;
  • Have a fundamental knowledge of the following systems:
            a) Root system;
            b) Aerial system (stem and leaves);
            c) Reproductive system (Flower, fruit and seeds)
  • Be able to recognise and describe the most important plant species for human use.

course_title: Plants for People, Plants for Life
college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud “Plants for People, Plants for Life” highlights the pivotal role of plants on our lives. This course aims to integrate descriptive knowledge of plant anatomy and morphology, together with biochemical and genetic mechanisms, in order to study functional processes ranging from seed germination to flowering and fruit set. It also focuses on the study of plant processes - how plants grow, develop and function as they interact with their physical (abiotic) and living (biotic) environments. Each process will be examined at the biochemical, cellular and organismal level so as to provide a more complete understanding of it. Furthermore, the last part of the course will focus on agro-ecology in order to give the students an overview about the current systems of plant production and the development of novel sustainable farming systems. During the course, up-to-date case studies will be presented in order to illustrate how the knowledge of plant ecophysiology and agro-ecology can be a useful tool to cope with increasing environmental and societal issues, such as climate change, food production, sustainable agriculture and environmental pollution.
  Leerdoelen After completing this course, the students will:
1. Be acquainted with the molecular mechanisms and the physiological processes that
shape and regulate plant life. This includes:
- How plants manufacture biological molecules (metabolism):
  • Photosynthesis – light and ‘dark’ reactions.
  • Respiration and lipid metabolism
  • Assimilation of inorganic nutrients (N, P, S)
- How plants acquire and transport inorganic and organic materials for growth:
  • Water balance and transport
  • Solute transport, translocation in the phloem and photosynthates distribution
- How plants grow and develop throughout their lives:
  • Embryogenesis: root and shoot apical meristems
  • Seed dormancy, germination and seedling establishment
  • Vegetative growth: leaf development, shoot branching and architecture, root
system architecture, secondary growth
  • Control of flowering and floral development
  • Signals and signal transduction: hormones and plant development.
  • Tropisms: growth in response to directional stimuli.
  • Plant senescence and plant death
- How plants interact with their external environment:
  • Biotic interactions
  • Abiotic environmental stress
2. Discover what is new in plant physiology.
Like most areas of biology, plant physiology is
experiencing an explosion of new discoveries and new ideas. We will discuss some of the
new topics in plant physiology and why they are considered important.
3. Understand that plant physiology relates to other fields in biology.
Most of you will never
be plant physiologists. For this course to be valuable to you, you must understand how plant
physiology interconnects with agricultural, forestry, environmental science, genetics, the
health sciences, and other fields. Throughout the course, connections between plant
physiology and other areas of knowledge will be emphasized.
4. Focus on how plant physiology will shape the future.
As students, you must consider the
future and your role in it. Plant biotechnology is putting plants to many new uses and
improving them for old ones. Plants can now be used to grow plastics and fuels, to remove
toxic wastes from soils, and to produce vaccines and drugs. Agriculture and forestry practices
have been altered by new crop varieties that resist stress, pathogens, herbicides, and postharvest
losses. These developments in plant biotechnology are derived from knowledge of
plant physiology and plant genetics. As scientists, business people, teachers, consumers,
voters, and parents, you must contribute to intelligent decisions about how plants should be
used to improve the human condition. To prepare you for this, we will discuss the role of
plant physiology in the future throughout the course.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Governments try to deal with complex issues, like flood protection, regeneration of urban neighborhoods, and the care for the young and elderly citizens. The context of these issues is often complex and dynamic. If contexts change, the issues changes. The straight forward and top down  implementation of a policy programs very often fail as many cases show. l. Policy initiatives and policy programs than evaporate without acceptable results. Where and why do governments end up in this kinds of inertia? However, other cases show the opposite. Where and why have other governments been able to deal with changing conditions in a more appropriate way and even use ‘the coincidences of change’ to achieve desired results? Why has policy innovation been realized?

 This core course of the master in Public Administration Rotterdam elaborates why policies mainly based on political and governmental desires without a systematic understanding of the complex context will often not solve the issue it is dealing with. We clarify how and why supply-oriented policy approaches create all kinds of implementation deficits. In order to deal effectively with complex issues policy makers have to increase their understanding of the complex contexts of issues. The course helps students to make system analysis, based on several theoretical approaches of complexity. Central theoretical concepts are co-evolution, feedback and self-organizing capacities
 
Successful implementation urges for the  connection of the development of policy programs with the real life worlds of citizens and semi public and private sector companies. We present an implementation oriented design of innovative policy programs. The coproduction of public and private organizations together with citizens, NGO’s and knowledge institutes can be improved by process design. Vital networks and chains are needed for effective process design. Leerdoelen
  1. The module presents a complex system perspective on governance environments and policy development and implementation processes. Policy processes evolves by positive and negative feedback, by co-evolution of processes and interactions in its context and by self-organizing capacities.
  2. The module increases your understanding of complexity and the inherent challenges in governing complex governance processes. What explanations does complexity theory generate for success and failure of large-scale policy programs? As a result you  will increase your capacities to apply complex system analysis.
  3. The module will also increase your abilities to cope with complexity. We will elaborate several implementation-oriented approaches for designing and redesigning policies: the formation of joint action in policy chains, the ability to organize reversed chain approaches starting bottom-up and coproduction in complex systems and networks.
  4. Elaborating modern governance and public sector innovation approaches: facilitating, smart small scale interventions, coproduction and meta-governance strategies in complex systems
  5. Applying methods and techniques for analyzing policy chains, public sector innovation and meta-governance
  6. High quality reflections on strength and weaknesses of the approaches presented.

course_title: Policy issues in public spending on education, health and labor
college: Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud Why do people vote against their economic self-interest? What is the connection between Brexit and Trump? What motivates a suicide bomber? Why do people throw themselves in the arms of authoritarian leaders like lemmings into the abyss? The rise of populism, cynicism, fanaticism and fundamentalism challenges us to reconsider the problem of ressentiment, a toxic brew of hatred, frustration, humiliation, indignation and passivity. Whereas its conceptualization dates back to the nineteenth century and has gradually dissolved in the course of twentieth century emancipatory processes, the concept of ressentiment is now making a comeback in political discourse.
The aims of this module are to explore the genealogy of this concept, to interpret the shifting political stakes that are expressed in it, and to evaluate the consistency and coherence with which it is currently put to use in public and academic discourse. We begin with a comparison of the concepts of resentment and ressentiment, relying on texts by Scottish enlighteners such as Joseph Butler and Adam Smith and comparing them to the texts on the untranslatable ressentiment (a French term, but a German concept) one century later by Soren Kierkegaard, Fiodor Dostoievski, and Max Scheler. We then proceed from a detailed reading of various texts by Nietzsche to a systematic mapping of the different ways and political contexts in which the concept has been reinvented in the humanities and the social sciences since. We study sources from political theory, literary history, and anthropology, and rely on a diversity of philosophical methods such as psychoanalysis, post-structuralism, critical theory, and existentialism. As we will see, ressentiment is one of those thorny issues that constantly threaten to compromise the one who speaks about it. There is no intrinsic good sense or evidency in the application of its concept and no universal criterion, but only a polemical sense. This means that the plausibility of the diagnosis of ressentiment, the real efficacy of its discursive ‘truth’, has to be proven in another way than merely in the dialectical form of a truth judgment. It cannot be abstracted from a political drama in which it takes on a different meaning depending on who uses it. Yet even if there is no a priori rule and no final argument that can mediate or solve this drama, there is nonetheless a philosophical systematicity or structure to be explored in it. Leerdoelen To acquire a solid grasp of the philosophical history of the concepts of resentment and ressentiment
To be able to recognize the different political stakes in the use of the concept of ressentiment functions in both public and academic discourse
To recognize and use various diverging and sometimes mutually contradicting theoretizations of ressentiment from the humanities and the social sciences
To analyze the affective infrastructure of the modern world with a focus on the reactive attitudes

course_title: Political Attitudes and Behaviour in Context
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['HB Broekema, MSc', 'prof.dr. J van der Waal']
text:
Inhoud The second course in the Politics & Society Master specialisation puts citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours in context: it focuses on the various institutional, cultural, and economic conditions relevant for understanding why political attitudes and behaviours differ across and within countries and change over time. It does so by discussing both classic and recent theories and research in the fields of political sociology and political science. The main institutional conditions addressed are political institutions, welfare regimes, and national media, as these prove to be crucial for understanding trends and cross-national differences in political trust, public opinion, and voting behaviour. The same goes for the cultural conditions addressed in this course, which most notably include regional and urban cultures, cultural and ethnic diversity, and religion and secularisation. The final part of the course focusses on the role of globalisation – especially its economic ramifications – for political attitudes and behaviour.
Besides providing in-depth insights into the relevance of contextual phenomena for individuals’ political attitudes and behaviour, this course stimulates sensitivity for recognizing unresolved and unexplored research puzzles. To this end students write a research proposal on how a context condition affects a political attitude or behaviour of their choice. As such, it equips students with key knowledge and skills needed for conducting their research for their Master’s thesis. In addition, it stimulates students to analyse and critically reflect on the contents and implications of social-scientific theories and research findings.
 
Note: basic knowledge of quantitative social-scientific methods is needed in order to understand a substantial part of the mandatory literature.


 
 
  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
 
  • Discuss cross-national similarities and differences in political institutions, party systems, welfare regimes, and policies relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
  • Explain theories that link these systems, welfare regimes, and policies to changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
  • Discuss the types and aspects of globalisation relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
  • Explain theories that link aspects of globalisation to changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
  • Explain theories that link media ecologies, regional and urban cultures, cultural and ethnic diversity, religion and secularisation to changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
  • Apply the above-mentioned social-scientific theories on the influence of contextual factors on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours to contemporary social phenomena;
  • Analyse the similarities and differences between social-scientific theories on the influence of contextual factors on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours;
  • Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on the influence of contextual factors on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours;
  • Utilise social-scientific theories on the influence of contextual factors on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours in a systematic and analytical way, as to formulate a theoretically relevant research question, using discriminating hypotheses, and/or sensitising concepts;
  • Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on the influence of contextual factors on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours on the basis of a written assignment;
  • Provide feedback on the work of fellow students.

course_title: Political Economy/Ecology of Agriculture and Environment
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['A Alonso Fradejas', 'C Sathyamala', 'dr. A Visser', 'dr. JF Gerber', 'dr. TM Shegro', 'prof.dr. BNF White', 'prof.dr. C Kay', 'prof.dr. M Arsel', 'prof.dr. SM Borras']

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course provides an action-oriented perspective on processes of public governance. The students will gain in-depth knowledge about the roles and behaviour of diverse stakeholders in the political process: governments, political parties, the legislature, interest groups, social movements, advisory committees and the corporate sector. Against the background of shifting responsibilities between state, market and society in the governance of policy sectors, student will learn how to become effective participants in processes of public governance as analysts, administrators or advocates.
This course develops a comparative perspective on the governance of policy sectors. In the course, we will explore a number of policy domains, including immigration, unemployment, public health and energy. For each of these cases we analyse the role of stakeholders, interactions and institutions in various stages of the policy process in a sample of European and non-European countries. Building upon their analysis of the policy fields and the institutional settings, students are challenged to develop effective strategies for influencing the governance of policy sectors.
Leerdoelen On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
  • Reflect on the current role and place of government in modern societies and describe their historical developments
  • Describe the role of a selected number of political institutions in modern states and reflect on their infuence and performance
  • Describe how governments design and implement policies
  • Reflect on the origins and backgrounds of governmental policies in various policy domains

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud The theme of this module is the significance and value of democracy in modern politics and administration. That there is such a value inherent to democracy is not self-evident in a world in which crisis- and conflict management and the effective design of policy arrangements seem to demand clear priority. However the democratic process may be organised, there remains a degree of unpredictability in the behaviour and choice of the demos (‘the people’), as history keeps on teaching us.

Within history as well, democracy was never fully accepted. There was always something to criticise, whether this be the lack of competent judgement of the people, the complexity of decision making, the interested self-seeking of the electorate or political parties, short term effect and the degree to which democracy was overwhelmed by media attention and emotion.

At the same time, political thinkers of the past were fascinated by the idea of self-rule; the notion that given an adequate organisational design, such a design might enable human beings to be genuinely autonomous and independent. Important ideas such as sovereignty, power, social contract, and even the idea of administration itself, were developed in this regard, occasionally also in opposition to the ‘plebeian threat’.

Nonetheless, it cannot be denied that in the course of time, gradually and often operating against the tide, a sense of politics and administration appeared whose principle is self-rule and that stands opposed to a technocratic idea of the political order. In this course the various stages within this development are identified and characterised in relation to current challenges of politics and administration. Different developments in thinking about democracy are discussed and their institutional realisation in administrative practices is explored. This means that not only the basic ideas and mechanisms underlying modern representative democracy are addressed, but also more recent inovations that aim to enlarge representative democracy with institutions for direct citizen participation. These same themes form the basis of the assignments carried out during the biweekly seminars.

The lectures and seminars in this course are fully integrated. The seminars are used to develop basic historical and philosophical skills that enable students to reflect on the contents of the lectures and thereby work towards a fresh understanding of the character of modern democratic politics and the history of the representative state in its current form. Attending the lectures and staying ahead with the course readings is absolutely essential in order to carry out the seminar assignments and prepare for the Individual portfolio assignment. Leerdoelen At the end of this module students can:
  • Explain the most important ideas within political philosophy concerning the emergence, development and challenges of modern democratic system
  • Research classical texts in the history of political philosophy;
  • Develop answers to fundamental questions about democracy, both normatively and empirically;
  • Explain topical disussions related to the democratic design of administrative practices in the present-day network society;
  • Based on an analysis of an administartive practice, assess its democratic content and quality.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud “And what should they know of England who only England know?” (Rudyard Kipling, author van The Jungle Book)

Politics is the process by which groups reach and enforce binding decisions. Power is the currency of politics. To survive, political systems need to force their members to do what they would not otherwise have done. Notwithstanding globalization, national political systems are still the main place for the legitimate execution of power. At the same time, nations differ widely in their institutions for political decision-making. This allows for comparison: learning more about other countries, and therewith about your own country, classifying characteristics of political systems, analysing their causes and consequences, predicting and evaluating the effects of societal and political-institutional change.

This course introduces students to the discipline of empirical political science. After having discussed the main concepts, we will compare and analyse various facets of national political systems. Democratic versus authoritarian systems, political trust, political communication and media, political cleavages, political parties, election rules and voting behavior, parliamentarian versus presidential governments, the structure and function of parliaments, and the role of constitutions and constitutional courts. Looking through the glasses of a political scientist, we seek to answer questions such as the following: Does trust in governments decline and what factors account for trust/distrust? What is the impact of social media on politics? Does globalization lead to new cleavages in society? What factors explain the rise of populist parties? Are coalition governments less stable than single-party governments? Are parliaments willing and able to control governments and are they representative of the electorate? Leerdoelen After passing the course, students are able to
  • define major political science concepts
  • reproduce major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems
  • compare major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems along relevant dimensions
  • explain causal theories about relationships between characteristics of political systems
  • evaluate the validity of causal theories based on existing data
  • predict the effect of societal and institutional changes on political phenomena
  • evaluate proposals for institutional change based on expected effects on relevant feature of political systems
  • develope and defend a position of a political group for negotiating a new constitution

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
text:
Inhoud
Almost everybody uses the term ‘policy’ now and then, and – although the term can be used in many different ways – we usually understand what is meant. Often policy is thought of as an artefact – a firm and definite thing constructed by policy makers (Colebatch, 2009). Often we think of policy processes as rational and linear processes that go through a number of stages: agenda setting, policy formulation, implementation, evaluation. We think that government institutions may make mistakes or are sometimes inefficient – but yet, it is usually assumed that they are working towards the public interest. 
 
In this course, we try to question this (assumed) rationality of policy and (assumed) benevolence of the bureaucracy. What exactly is this dominant ‘idea of policy’; why is it so strong, and what are its implications? What are alternative ways of understanding policy? An alternative understanding focuses inevitable more on politics. The ‘idea of policy’ as a rational process is itself a political construction; moreover, processes of administration, management, budgeting and reform are also inherently political. 
 
The course will also include one full session in which we discuss how to write a book review. 
Leerdoelen
Upon completion of the course, students will 
1)  have increased their theoretical understanding of the concept of policy. They will be familiar with some of the insights about the ‘social construction of policy’ and understand the implications of the dominant ‘idea of policy’ as a rational, goal-oriented process
2)  have become familiar with ideas and theories about the inherently political nature of the bureaucracy
3)  have acquired some skills to apply these theoretical insights to cases of policies familiar to them
4)  have improved their skills in communicating these insights to a larger audience orally and in a written form.
5) have improved their skills to read academic literature and discuss it critically.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. I van Breugel', 'dr. M Schiller', 'dr. Z Kasli', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']
text:
Inhoud

Migration and diversity are key political topics of our time. This course focuses both on the role that migration and diversity play in politics and policies and vice versa. To what extent are contemporary political debates on migration and diversity really new? What role do different levels of governance have in the fields of migration and diversity? How well are immigrants and ethnic minorities themselves represented in politics?

 

This course focuses not only on contemporary politics and policymaking, but also on how migration and diversity have evolved as topics in politics and governance across and beyond Europe. It provides an overview of citizenship models and, related to these models, different types of migration, integration and diversity policies. Furthermore, the course introduces students to contemporary conceptual debates on the management of different types of migration flows as well as to the different scales and levels of migration policies, from local, national, regional to the global. Finally, the course unpacks politicization of migration with due attention to its manifestation in party politics, political movements and media.

Leerdoelen

At the end of this course, students will be able to

 

·         Identify the links between political structures and migration and diversity policies

·         Test theoretical models of citizenship and migration management in the face of new political developments and/or mobility practices

·         Compare migration and diversity policies at different levels (local, national, regional, global) in specific cases

·         Assess contemporary migration and diversity policies in relation to past policies and historical developments

·         Analyze the roles that different state and nonstate actors, including migrants, play in politics and management of migration and diversity

·         Apply existing theoretical concepts and frameworks to current events

·         Develop presentation and argumentation skills

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. MKA Kniou', 'prof.dr. W Hout', 'S Hardus, MSc']

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Politieke communicatie bestudeert de communicatie tussen burgers, media en politieke actoren zoal politici en politieke partijen. In deze cursus worden deze actoren geanalyseerd: welke communicatiestrategieën gebruiken politici en partijen, hoe berichten journalisten over politieke kwesties en welke betekenis hebben deze processen voor burgers en de democratie? Studenten analyseren literatuur over politieke communicatie en reflecteren aan de hand van praktijkvoorbeelden op die literatuur. Door middel van kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden bestuderen zij een hedendaags vraagstuk op het terrein van politieke communicatie. In deze cursus zal de vraag centraal staan hoe populistische politici proberen een publiek aan zich te binden en hoe het publiek op deze politici reageert. Studenten formuleren op dit terrein een onderzoeksopzet en voeren dit onderzoek tijdens de tweede helft van de module uit.
 
NB: het maximum aantal studenten is 18. De workshop is alleen toegankelijk voor MA M&J studenten.
  Leerdoelen

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The objective of this course is to expose students to both fundamental concepts and cutting edge theories and tools in portfolio management. We will cover optimal portfolio construction techniques and models such (such as Black-Litterman, Treynor-Black) and transaction costs. We will learn about the law of active management with a comparison the active vs. passive portfolio management (i.e. how active (mutual funds) managers perform). The course will also include paper presentations on anomalies, investor sentiment, and factor investing. Case studies will be used to illustrate the various methodologies introduced in this course. Moreover, exercises with real financial data will be the part of the course.
 
  Leerdoelen After having followed this course, students will acquire essential skills for optimal portfolio construction, incorporating investors’ views into optimal (i.e. mean-variance) portfolios, passive vs. active investing, understanding the law of active investing, and a broad understanding of frictions in the capital markets.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. LM van der Lugt', 'dr.ir. AK Bhoopalam', 'HW White, MSc', 'prof.dr. AW Veenstra', 'prof.dr. RA Zuidwijk', 'prof.dr.ir. R Dekker', 'R van den Berg, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
The seaport of Rotterdam is the main gateway to the European market, although it is much more than a node in which cargo is transferred between ship and shore. The quality and competitiveness of the port is determined by its position in networks, both at a local level, and at a global level. These networks are transport links with the other major ports in the world – Singapore, Shanghai, Dubai, New York/New Jersey, and the major ports in Europe Antwerp, Hamburg, Bremen, Le Havre, and multimodal transport links with the main destinations in the European hinterland. In addition, the port is also a network of industrial activity that facilitates a large number of supply chains with transport, storage, production and other activities. Finally, the port is embedded in a network of information exchange that enables safe and secure port operations, the efficient management of transportation in and around the port, and the smooth flow of goods through the port.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
This course aims to provide a sound understanding of the role of the port in global networks, and let students gain experience with the development of new and innovative solutions for current problems that exist in this complex context. The elective will provide a variety of perspectives on the port from a number of disciplines, including port management, legal aspects, public administration aspects, and business economic aspects. The assessment consists of an individual assignment, four team assignments, and participation.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. DAJA Derks - Theunissen', 'dr. MJ Gorgievski', 'dr. P Petrou']
text:
Inhoud Doordat veel productie de laatste jaren is verplaatst naar het Verre Oosten, is het werken met het hoofd (met informatie) en met het hart (met mensen) een steeds groter onderdeel gaan uitmaken van werkactiviteiten in de moderne Westerse maatschappij. Hierdoor zijn menselijke hulpbronnen doorslaggevend geworden voor het concurrerend voordeel dat bedrijven behalen. In deze minor ligt het accent op het managen van medewerkers (blok 1: Psychological Capital), en het managen van de eigen emoties in de interacties met klanten, collega’s, de leidinggevende, en ondergeschikten (blok 2: Emotion Management). Voorbeelden van onderwerpen die in deze minor op een toegankelijke manier worden behandeld zijn: welke persoonlijke kenmerken en organisatiekenmerken vergroten de kans op bevlogenheid bij werknemers? Waarom leidt bevlogenheid tot betere prestaties? Hoe kun je het beste je eigen en andermans emoties managen? Zijn emoties besmettelijk? Wat houdt emotionele intelligentie precies in? Leerdoelen De minor is interessant voor alle studenten met belangstelling voor de psychologie van het werken in organisaties en biedt een unieke aanvulling op het kennisrepertoire van economen en bedrijfskundigen. Studenten van de eigen psychologie opleiding zijn uitgesloten van deelname aan deze minor. Concrete leerdoelen:
  • Studenten dienen inzicht te verwerven in de basale principes van het functioneren van mensen in organisaties;
  • Studenten nemen kennis van verschillende organisatiepsychologische onderwerpen, zoals de rol van positieve emoties op de werkvloer, bevlogenheid, personeelsselectie, de beoordeling en beloning van personeel, emotionele arbeid, emotiemanagement, emotionele intelligentie, en de impact van deze fenomenen op prestaties.
  • Studenten verwerven inzicht in het managen van zowel de eigen emoties als die van anderen in de context van organisaties.

course_title: Post-Colonial Theory: Critical Perspectives from the Global South
college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud
This course will engage with theoretical discussions in postcolonial studies. Through texts by some of the major theorists of the field, such as Edward Said, Homi Bhabha and Gayatri Charkavorty Spivak, we will critically examine the cultural logic of colonialism, neo-colonialism and imperialism as well as their present-day remnants. In addition, we will explore processes of decolonisation, not only of lands, but also of cultures, identities and minds. The Other, hybridity, orientalism and the subaltern are among the concepts that we will take up and mobilise to these ends. In the most general sense, this course will provide a framework to critically assess notions of Western modernity, civilisation and historiography.
Leerdoelen After this course, students will be able to:
- Conceptually define colonialism, neo-colonialism, imperialism and postcolonialism.
- Understand and describe some of the major ideas in postcolonialism, like Edward Said's Orientalism.
- Understand and describe some of the major theoretical debates within postcolonialsm.
- Understand and describe some of the concepts that are linked to decolonisation of culture, land and the mind.
- Understand and describe the present-day relevancy of the vantages that postcolonialism offers.

college: Erasmus School of Economics

course_title: Poverty, Gender and Social Protection: Debates, Policies and Transformative Interventions
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['E van der Wal, MSc', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Tijdens het practicum Academische Schrijfvaardigheden I werken studenten thuis en tijdens de practicumbijeenkomsten aan een wetenschappelijk literatuurverslag, waarbij de nadruk wordt gelegd op het samenhangend en gestructureerd verwerken van literatuur aan de hand van een wetenschappelijke onderzoeksvraag.
Het practicum is onderverdeeld in twee delen, het eerste deel vindt plaats tijdens blok 1.7 en het tweede deel tijdens blok 1.8. In het eerste deel van het practicum ligt de focus op de voorbereidende fase van het schrijven, met aandacht voor het kritisch lezen en evalueren van literatuur, het formuleren van een wetenschappelijke onderzoeksvraag en het opstellen van een structuuropzet van het verslag. Daarnaast volgen studenten een bibliotheekpracticum waarin ze een training krijgen in het zoeken van  wetenschappelijke literatuur door gebruik te maken van wetenschappelijke databanken.
In het tweede deel van het practicum ligt de focus op het schrijven en reviseren van het literatuurverslag. Tijdens de practicumbijeenkomsten wordt aandacht besteed aan de verschillende onderdelen van het verslag (inleiding, middenstuk, conclusie en discussie, referentielijst) en wordt er stilgestaan bij relevante aspecten van het academisch schrijven (structuur, samenhang en cohesie, refereren, argumentatie en wetenschappelijke schrijfstijl). Studenten worden tijdens het schrijfproces ondersteund door speciale computerprogramma’s die extra uitleg en oefening bieden over bepaalde aspecten van het schrijven. Deze programma’s heten schrijf-ViP’s, waar ViP staat voor Vaardigheden in de Psychologie. Daarnaast krijgen studenten feedback van elkaar en van de tutor op elkaars stukken. Op basis hiervan verbeteren en reviseren studenten hun eigen verslag.
Toetsvorm: Literatuurverslag Leerdoelen
Aan het einde van de cursus Academische Schrijfvaardigheden I moet je een helder, goed gestructureerd, samenhangend literatuurverslag kunnen schrijven, met correct gebruik van bronnen (referenties) en zonder fouten in grammatica en interpunctie.
Het verslag moet de actuele stand van het onderzoek op een bepaald vakgebied of op het gebied van een bepaald thema of probleem in kaart brengen. Hierbij moet eerder uitgevoerd onderzoek objectief worden beschouwd en moeten verbanden, tegenstrijdigheden, ontbrekende informatie en inconsistenties in de literatuur worden beschreven.
 
Aan het einde van de cursus beheers je de volgende vaardigheden:
  • Het formuleren van een wetenschappelijke vraag
  • Het zoeken en beoordelen van literatuur op relevantie
  • Het kritisch lezen en evalueren van wetenschappelijke bronnen
  • Het opstellen van een structuuropzet voor het verslag
  • Het helder beantwoorden van een wetenschappelijke vraag in de vorm van een goed gestructureerd literatuurverslag
  • Het toepassen van de APA-regels voor het verwijzen naar bronnen
  • Het toepassen van de vuistregels uit de schrijf-ViP's

course_title: Practical Attitudes and Emotions in Organisations
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. P Petrou', 'KA Pekaar, MSc', 'MEL Zeijen, MSc']
text:
Leerdoelen Het practicum is gericht op psychologische observatie- en meetmethoden binnen de context van arbeidsorganisaties.
 
Het practicum is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
You will work with paper and digital atlases, and you will also have a look at a real human brain. A post mortem brain that is! In two demonstration practical meetings at the medical Faculty, a human brain will be dissected. Atlases and anatomy books can teach you much about brain anatomy, but a dissection of the human brain is most instructive in getting a 3-dimensional overview of the brain. Furthermore, we will have three training sessions in the computer rooms in which we work with digital sources.
Leerdoelen
At the end of this practical you will have profound knowledge of the anatomy of the human brain. Also, by making the assignments in this workbook, you will have made your own atlas, which might be very useful during the later courses in the Master B&C.
You will be able to identify and describe:
  • the four cerebral lobes and the main gyri and sulci of the lobes
  • the structures on the midsagital plane
  • the white matter tracts in the brain
  • the structures that belong to the ventricular system
  • the structures that belong to the limbic system
  • the structures that belong to the basal ganglia
  • the structures of the diencephalon ( de tussenhersenen )
  • the structures of the brain stem and the cerebellum
  • the layers that protect the brain from the outside

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. LP Dekker', 'dr. RER Van der Hallen']
text:
Inhoud During this practical we will focus on CBT’s rationale, learn how to distinguish between thoughts, emotions and behaviour, how to conduct a CBT case assessment, including how to conduct a CBT assessment interview, and how to compile a CBT case formulation, including the maintenance cycle, a chain analysis and the ABC technique. In addition to that, students will learn how to recognise different types of cognitive distortions, how to understand these distortions in light of different psychological and psychiatric conditions, and how to challenge a client’s disrupting thoughts in a helpful and constructive manner.
Students will use pen-and-paper exercises as well as role play in order to learn and practice these assessment techniques and become familiar with CBT case assessment.
  Leerdoelen The aims for this practical are to learn all about Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), its rationale as well as how to read, understand and analyse a case or client in terms of the underlying (dysfunctional) cognitive and behavioural patterns.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. LP Dekker', 'dr. RER Van der Hallen']

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In dit practicum leren de studenten dat het anamnestisch interview een belangrijk instrument is om een DSM diagnose te stellen. Ze leren hierbij om symptomen van psychopathologie te herkennen en om op basis daarvan een adequate DSM diagnose te stellen. Tevens leren ze om differentiaal-diagnostisch te denken. Tenslotte oefenen de studenten in rollenspelen met het zelf uitvoeren van (delen van) een anamnestisch interview. Hierbij is het interview opgesplitst in de klachtenanamnese, de psychiatrische anamnese, de biografische anamnese en de sociale anamnese.
 
Het practicum is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP). Leerdoelen
Het doel van het practicum ‘Anamnestisch Interview’ is
  • het leren voeren van een anamnesegesprek,
  • het op basis van deze gespreks- en observatiegegevens kunnen stellen van een DSM-(5-)diagnose,
  • het op basis van deze diagnose kunnen voorstellen van een voorlopig behandelplan
  • het kunnen rapporteren van deze gegevens in een diagnostisch (anamnestisch) rapport.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
De basishouding en de basisgespreksvaardigheden, die men nodig heeft voor het voeren van een professioneel gesprek, worden geoefend in 'tweegesprekken', dat wil zeggen: gesprekken waarbij slechts twee personen betrokken zijn. De setting is er vaak één, waarin iemand zich met een persoonlijk probleem of een probleem op het werk tot een hulpverlener wendt. Het gaat dan om een eerste gesprek tussen de hulpverlener en de cliënt. Een dergelijk probleemverhelderingsgesprek leent zich goed voor het oefenen van de basishouding en de basisvaardigheden, die van belang zijn voor mensen die beroepsmatig gesprekken met cliënten moeten voeren.
 
Leerdoelen Het doel van het practicum Gespreksvoering I is het vergroten van kennis van en inzicht en vaardigheid in effectief communiceren. Studenten leren een aantal veelgebruikte basisgespreksvaardigheden toe te passen en verdiepen hun inzicht in de theoretische kennis door het zelf oefenen in gesimuleerde, professionele gesprekken.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Communicatieve vaardigheden zijn niet louter uit een boekje te leren. Daarvoor is ook praktische oefening en feedback nodig. De aanpak waarvoor wij gekozen hebben, is gebaseerd op de cumulatieve microtraining methode (CMT) van Lang en Van der Molen (1992). Deze methode is op haar beurt weer gebaseerd op de sociaal-leertheoretische benadering van Bandura (1977, 1986). In die benadering wordt ervan uitgegaan dat sociaal en cultureel gedrag aangeleerd is en dat eventuele inadequate sociale gedragingen ook afgeleerd kunnen worden. Hieronder bespreken we hoe we deze methode in het practicum zullen gebruiken.

Cumulatieve microtraining (CMT)
