De centrale doelstelling van de praktijkstage is kennis maken met de beroepspraktijk. Dit doe je door een stageopdracht uit te voeren in een instelling binnen de gezondheidszorg (zorginstelling, zorgverzekeraar, overheid, consultancy). Je kunt stagelopen in Nederland, maar ook in het buitenland. De stageperiode is van begin maart tot eind mei. Dit loopt parallel aan het bachelorscriptietraject. Met toestemming van de stagecoördinator is het ook mogelijk om in een andere periode binnen het academisch jaar stage te lopen

Omvang
De stage heeft een omvang van 240 uur werken in de stage-instelling; de overige uren zijn gereserveerd voor het werken aan het stage-portfolio voor de opleiding. In dat portfolio werk je aan verschillende opdrachten.

Onderwijs en toetsing
Werkvormen
  • Intervisiebijeenkomsten
  • Werkstuk(ken)
  • StageToetsing
  • Portfolio (VD)
  • Beoordeling stagebegeleider (VD)

Meer informatie?
Op de website https://www.eur.nl/eshpm/stage-werken-de-zorg vind je meer informatie voor studenten én stage-instellingen over de eisen aan de stage.
De stage heeft ook een eigen e-mailadres: stage@eshpm.eur.nl. Gebruik dit adres als je de coördinator wilt bereiken.

course_title: Praktische Filosofie: Ethiek, rationaliteit en emotie II: enactivisme
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud Het lichaam-geest dualisme  is  een berucht  struikelblok voor emotieonderzoekers:  vinden emoties hun oorsprong in fysieke mechanismen die evolutionair verankerd zijn in het brein, of in culturele cognitieve oordelen? Empirisch en filosofisch emotieonderzoek verslikt zich al honderd jaar  in dit  dilemma  en is daardoor niet in staat de existentiële,  praktische en morele dimensie van emoties scherp te krijgen.
Deze cursus onderzoekt in hoeverre het enactivisme  - een filosofie die uitgaat van de intrinsieke samenhang van biologie en betekenis, lichaam en geest, persoon en wereld, ‘feeling’ en cognitie - verandering in de  situatie brengt. De cursus vertrekt van vier grote denkers  over emotie: James, Wittgenstein, Heidegger en Sartre, en  traceert hun doorwerking in de ‘enactivistische’ emotiefilosofie van de 21e eeuw  (Matthew Ratcliffe,  Giovanna Colombetti, Jan Slaby, e.a.).
Aan het eind van de cursus discussiëren we over de waarde van het enactivisme voor actueel emotieonderzoek: worden hier de contouren zichtbaar van een nieuwe,  integrerende theorie van emoties en affectiviteit?     
  Leerdoelen Inzicht krijgen in de historisch-filosofische achtergronden  en de actuele betekenis van het enactivisme voor hedendaagse visies op emoties en praktische rationaliteit.
Begrijpen hoe de enactivistische benadering  van  affectiviteit  zich onderscheidt van traditionele cognitivistische en non-cognitivistische  emotietheorieën.
Kunnen uitleggen wat het belang is van ‘embodied emotions’ voor thema’s  binnen de  morele psychologie en ethiek  zoals:  vrije wil & akrasia,  praktische rationaliteit & cognitieve irrationaliteit,  empathie &  intersubjectiviteit, zelfbewustzijn,  zelfbedrog &  immoraliteit.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. A van Prooijen', 'dr. AE Necula, PhD', 'dr. AMM Hermans']
text:
Inhoud Students complete their Pre-master programme by writing a Pre-master thesis. Although the Pre-master thesis is completed individually, students receive guidance while working on the thesis by means of a weekly thesis class, which starts in term 3 and continues into term 4. The classes are arranged around themes in accordance with the focus areas of IBCoM. In consultation with the lecturer, students develop a research question that is related to the wider theme of their thesis class.

The Pre-master Thesis Class starts with a discussion of potential research subjects and addressing background literature as well as relevant research methods. The main part of the course concerns conducting the actual research. Students are invited to submit questions and to talk about the progress and results of their research.

The Pre-master thesis is a reflection of the knowledge and research skills obtained in the field of Communication and Media. In addition, the Pre-master thesis is designed to further train students' ability to develop, conduct and report on a theoretically informed, practically relevant, empirical study. Leerdoelen The Pre-master Thesis Class offers students guidance in formulating an appropriate and relevant research question and in structuring and conducting research in the field of Communication and Media. After the Pre-master Thesis Class, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and report on this research in their thesis.

course_title: Premaster Thesis Class Media & Creative Industries
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
The Pre-master Thesis Class Media & Creative Industries offers students guidance in formulating an appropriate and relevant research question and in structuring and conducting research in the field of Communication and Media. After the Pre-master Thesis Class, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and report on this research in their thesis.

The theme of this course is Culture, Media & Journalism. Next to discussing key questions surrounding this theme, the focus will also be on qualitative research methods. We will devote attention to the formulation of a qualitative research question, the importance of a theoretical framework and suitable methods of data collection and analysis.
​
Please note that passing grades for the Pre-Master Thesis Class are only valid in the academic year they were obtained. Students who fail the Pre-Master Thesis in block 4 (after the re-sit) need to enroll in an entire new Pre-Master Thesis Class trajectory the next academic year.
Leerdoelen Students complete their Pre-master programme by writing a Pre-master thesis. Although the Pre-master thesis is completed individually, students receive guidance while working on the thesis by means of a weekly thesis class, which starts in term 3 and continues into term 4.

The Pre-master Thesis Class starts with a discussion of potential research subjects and addressing background literature as well as relevant research methods. The main part of the course concerns conducting the actual research. Students are invited to submit questions and to talk about the progress and results of their research.

The Pre-master thesis is a reflection of the knowledge and research skills obtained in the field of Communication and Media. In addition, the Pre-master thesis is designed to further train students' ability to develop, conduct and report on a theoretically informed, practically relevant, empirical study.

course_title: Premaster Thesis Class Media en Journalistiek
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
Deze premaster thesis class richt zich op onderzoek op het terrein van politieke communicatie: het vakgebied over de wisselwerking tussen politiek, media en burgers. Hierin staan vragen centraal als: hoe presenteren politici en politieke partijen zich in het publieke domein, welke overwegingen hebben zij, hoe verslaan journalisten de politiek, welke invloed hebben de media op het politieke bedrijf, hoe komen burgers aan hun politieke informatie en in hoeverre worden zij voldoende geïnformeerd over de politiek?
Tijdens deze module werken studenten aan een onderzoeksplan voor de premaster thesis. De module start met het verwerken van basisliteratuur, waarna studenten zelf op zoek gaan naar een onderwerp en bijpassende theorie. Studenten formuleren zelfstandig een wetenschappelijk relevante onderzoeksvraag en bepalen op welke manier ze deze vraag kunnen beantwoorden. Dit alles resulteert in een onderzoeksplan wat aan het einde wordt beoordeeld. Het onderzoek voeren studenten uit in blok 4.
 
N.B. Dit vak is uitsluitend toegankelijk voor studenten die het schakelprogramma Media en Journalistiek volgen
 
Leerdoelen
Na afloop van deze module kunnen studenten:
  • zelfstandig een vraagstelling formuleren die als uitgangspunt dienst voor verder onderzoek;
  • diverse (primaire) bronnen in het onderzoek betrekken en daar kritisch mee omgaan;
  • theoretische en methodologische concepten toepassen bij het onderzoek;
  • een mondelinge presentatie van het onderzoeksplan verzorgen;
  • een voorstel voor een zelfstandig verder uit te voeren thesisonderzoek schrijven.

course_title: Premaster Thesis Class Media, Culture & Society
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval', 'dr. CE Aalberts', 'dr. N Mena Montes']
text:
Inhoud The Pre-master Thesis Class starts with a discussion of potential research subjects and addressing background literature as well as relevant research methods in the field of Communication and Media. The theme that will be dealt with in this Pre-master Thesis Class: Media Agenda and Frames in times of Crisis: events media hypes, politicians and public opinion. After the Pre-master Thesis Class, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and report on this research in their thesis. Leerdoelen
Students have knowledge and understanding of:
- The fundamentals of research methodology and theories
- The roadmap and the steps that they have to follow in order to write a thesis.
 
Students have developed the skills to:
- To find a research question and design a project to answer it.
- To develop, conduct and report on a theoretical academic level
- To do research using qualitative methodology

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. A van Prooijen', 'dr. AE Necula, PhD', 'dr. AMM Hermans', 'dr. CE Aalberts', 'dr. N Mena Montes', 'RCW Koreman, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Studenten ronden hun schakeljaar af met het schrijven van een premaster thesis. Deze thesis vormt een weergave van de opgedane kennis en onderzoeksvaardigheden op het terrein van Media & Journalistiek. Daarnaast is de pre-master thesis bedoeld om studenten de kans te geven hun opgedane vaardigheden met het vormgeven, verrichten en beschrijven van empirisch onderzoek verder te ontwikkelen.

De premaster thesis is een individueel te verrichten activiteit. Tijdens het werken aan de thesis is er echter begeleiding in de vorm van individuele en groepsbijeenkomsten. Leerdoelen Van studenten wordt verwacht dat zij zelfstandig, maar wel onder begeleiding van een docent:
  • een bepaald onderwerp op een vooraf breed vastgesteld terrein van Media & Journalistiek verder kunnen afbakenen en bestuderen;
  • Onderzoek verrichten en daarvan verslag leggen;
  • een thesis schrijven die naar inhoud, compositie en taalgebruik aan wetenschappelijke eisen voldoet.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. LAL de Meijer', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc', 'S Schouwenburg']
text:
Inhoud The internship is an introduction with the professional practice and an exercise in the skills which are relevant in the profession. The students gain experience in applying knowledge and at the same time acquire new knowledge and skills. During the internship 7 points for attention are central. These 7 points are important during the internship and the reporting of the internship. At each point of attention is formulated a number of objectives. These objectives apply to all forms of internship. The starting point is that all objectives be realized during the internship at the institution. However, due the nature of the different forms of internship certain objectives will be more or less on the foreground. The internship committee determines whether there can be met within the placement to the different objectives (based on the internship request). Leerdoelen
The Master internship is an important component of the Master Family Pedagogy. During the first phase of the Master you have gained pedagogicalal knowledge and skills, now is the time to apply this acquired knowledge and skills into practice. The internship is the opportunity to deepen or broaden your content. This internship can give you a good overview of the labor market, the field and the requirements of employers. You can gain work experience and make valuable contacts, which you can use in your future career.

Knowledge and insight
The student has knowledge and insight of:
• work within the pedagogical and/or educational profession at local level and/or at (inter)national level and the way in which these activities are relate to other institutions that directly or indirectly deal with issues in education and parenting.
• current pedagogical and/or educational issues and the current state of science and/or practice.
• the policy, protocols and/or processes of professionals in the pedagogical and/or educational professions.
• diversity issues within the pedagogical and/or educational practice and/or science.
• ethical and legal frameworks for pedagogical and/or educational act.
• performing and interpreting scientific pedagogical and/or educational research.

Application of Knowledge and insights
The student is able to:
• apply the scientific knowledge (acquired during the study) in the professional practice.
• translate complex pedagogical and/or educational problems to (potential for) suitable interventions, programs and/or policies and to carry a valid basis.
• share professional development with professionals in the field.

Critcal appraisal
The student is able to:
• reflect scientifically on pedagogical and/or educational ethical issues.
• reflect scientifically and ethical on the interaction between the interest of science, policy and practice.
• oversee the research process and the diagnostic cycle.
• make responsible ethical and procedural decisions during the diagnostic and research cycle.
• reflect critical on their own insights and skills and those of others.

Skills
The student is able to:
• apply, under supervision, (diagnostic) instruments, even at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• report, scientifically sound, in written and oral form about plans and research (both focused on treatment/ intervention and research itself) and resulting recommendations, problems and solutions.
• assume an academic / advisory role in a cooperative relationship with professionals.
• select relevant scientific literature.
• set up, execute and evaluate a research or intervention or training programme in the field of education and/or parenting problems, preferably also at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• provides a scientific contribution to (developing) policy, practice or research within an pedagogical context.

Communication
The student is able to:
• work in a multidisciplinary group in pedagogical and/or educational practice.
• cooperate and communicate with different target groups (such as children, parents, teachers, policymakers and scientists).
• cooperate and communicate effectively and respectful with individuals with different backgrounds (such as nationality, culture, socio-economic environment and scientific discipline).

Learning skills
The student is able to:
• directing their own learning process.
• ask for feedback on the work carried out, and here to receive to deal adequate with it.
• reflect on their own learning (and development herein) and to determine what are personal goals and interests.

Personal goals
In addition to the objectives set out the course, the student will also formulate personal goals to encourage the professional development.

The domains, independence (ig. Mostly know him/her to do, take action itself), establish contacts (ig. Can cooperate professionally with different target groups), communication (ig. Has good listening and communication skills) and professionalism (ig. respects appointments, is open to and processed on an adequate feedback), are important aspects herein.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. LAL de Meijer', 'dr. MHF Deutz', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc', 'S Schouwenburg']
text:
Inhoud
The master’s thesis is the final part of the master program. During this final phase, students apply their knowledge and skills in the field of pedagogical and educational research. By formulating relevant academic research questions and carrying out a subsequent research, students contribute to the collective knowledge base of professionals and academics in the field of pedagogy and education.
The master thesis is an academic written product, an academic aptitude test in which students reflect their academic level. The master thesis describes empirical research in form of an academic article and contributes to the knowledge of pedagogical or educational science.
Leerdoelen
After finishing the master's thesis
Students have knowledge of:
  • current insights, key theories, empirical findings, and national and international developments, both within the chosen specialization and at the interface of the three specializations (i.e. ortho pedagogy, family pedagogy and educational sciences);
  • cultural (i.e. ethnic-cultural, ethical and/or legal), economic, social and/or political developments within the chosen specialization, and related issues, problems and findings (including empirical findings);
  • advanced methods and models used in the process of signaling and identifying complex, multi-problem pedagogical situations and providing appropriate guidance and support, both at the level of the individual and at the level of systems and institutions;
  • intervention (or treatment) models of complex, multiple pedagogical problems, including their effectiveness and their application in a diverse context (i.e. diversity in ethnic-culture, social-economic status, legislation, language, gender);
  • advanced designs and methods for social sciences research.
Students are able to:
  • assess and translate complex pedagogical problems into interventions, programs and/or policy, and  analyze and evaluate them;
  • carry out research within the chosen specialization and at the interface with other related sub disciplines of the pedagogical sciences;
  • analyze complex questions, issues and developments in the field of upbringing and education and form a well-reasoned opinion by integrating existing knowledge and their own understanding with the ability to reflect on the limitations of their knowledge and on the influence of their own and other people’s culture-based norms and values;
  • carry out their pedagogic and scientific work with an awareness of ethical and culture-related aspects, in respect of clients as well as test subjects, and to oversee the consequences of their own professional actions;
  • work in a multidisciplinary group in a pedagogical context, and competently take on either a leading role or a team role;
  • communicate complex themes, either orally or in writing, in a clear and comprehensible way, with the ability to differentiate between different target groups (e.g. children, parents, teachers, policymakers, scientists and other professionals) and accounting for diversity;
  • keep up with subject-related developments and developments in society in order to contribute to change processes in pedagogic practice and to innovation in the field of pedagogy; independently engage in a further specialist study program and continue working on their professional development.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. TAB Dollevoet', 'dr. W van den Heuvel']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Session One:
  • Introductions
  • Feedback exchange
  • Managing nervousness
  • Body parts
  • Getting their attention
  • Introducing yourself
  • Using the stage
  • Leveraging interaction
  • Managing Q&A
  • Managing hostility

Session Three:

Leerdoelen

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
text:
Inhoud Workshops of 4 - 6 sessions each (8 - 12hours) will be offered thrice a year between February - April and October –December. This will depend on the number of participants enrolled. 
Minimum of 4 participants need to enroll for the program to begin.
Those wishing to take the course need to register with the course leader mahmud@iss.nl.

Participation in the course also helps when taking part in conferences and seminars outside ISS.
 
Being a hands-on training program, the course entails making presentations, structuring the text and preparing visuals.
 
Individual guidance will be offered, if required, esp. for Full Draft seminars and Public Defence (ISS-EGSH-0004).
  Leerdoelen The purpose of the workshops is to guide and train participants for the PhD seminars: Dissertation Design Seminar, Full Draft Dissertation Seminar and finally for the Public Defence.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Accounting is the language of business. Given that the role profile of financial managers has broadened substantially in recent years with a particular emphasis on management skills, accounting and financial management graduates from our programme more than ever need to be able to communicate the key implications of this (sometimes complicated) language to a variety of different audiences in a convincing and easy manner.

Therefore, the department of Accounting and Control offers this 1 ECTS course to provide students with the necessary tools for preparing a good presentation and communicating its key messages effectively. It is mandatory for all incoming students in accounting and financial management.

The course format will be multiple sessions with experienced coaches from the J-building and companies. To pass this course, students will need to attend the sessions. An alternative assessment format will be to prepare a presentation on a subject recorded on video.
 
Leerdoelen
Students in this course will learn
  • How to prepare a clear presentation structure
  • How to create quality slides for different areas and audiences, such as research, real life cases, or executive summaries
  • How to make impact on the audience
  • How to present themselves effectively

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
text:
Inhoud After this course students are able to:
  • To apply the technology-entrepreneurship-development perspective nexus to real life challenges in frugal innovation;
  • To work in multidisciplinary groups, and relate this knowledge to and integrate into their own disciplinary background;
  • From there, make a constructive contribution to the debate on frugal innovation and sustainable global development.
Leerdoelen Part A of the minor is concluded with a pressure cooker in which students apply the acquired knowledge in Part A to arrive at a number of detailed ideas for a Frugal Innovation that can contribute to solving a concrete problem within one of the SDGs. In doing so, they have to consider and think through and combine elements from the Technology-Entrepreneurship- Development perspectives. Cases / problems are obtained from the practice of companies and NGOs that will be invited to do provide ‘challenges’. The outcome of the pressure cooker are reports, video presentations or any other different visual or written form (determined in consultation with the client), which is presented to the company or the NGO at the end of the pressure cooker. Outcomes of the pressure cooker can serve as preparation for and input of the internship for those students who do an internship. For students from the EUR for whom this minor is a 15 ECTS minor, the pressure cooker is the concluding part of the minor.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. G van Eijk', 'dr. TFC Fischer', 'IM Mooren, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SR Matthijsse, MSc']
text:
Inhoud ‘Preventie en bestraffing’ gaat over de verschillende manieren waarop we reageren op criminaliteit. Het gaat dan in de eerste plaats om straf. Straf is niet alleen een reactie achteraf, maar de dreiging van straf dient ook om criminaliteit te voorkomen. We bespreken in dit vak uitgebreid het onderzoek naar de effectiviteit van verschillende vormen van preventie van criminaliteit, zowel door straf, als door sociale en situationele interventies. We kijken ook naar ontwikkelingen in het bestraffingsbeleid, in historisch en internationaal perspectief. Hoe soft of streng is Nederland in vergelijking tot andere landen en hoe heeft het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid zich ontwikkeld in de afgelopen 30 jaar? Deze ontwikkelingen worden geduid met behulp van het begrip controlecultuur. De hoorcolleges bieden verdieping door een beeld te schetsen van de zwaarste detentie- en sanctieregimes, te weten TBS, levenslange gevangenisstraf, de Extra Beveiligde Inrichting en de ISD.
Leerdoelen Studenten doen in dit vak kennis op van de verschillende strafdoelen en hun onderlinge relatie en de mate waarin zij in het huidige sanctiebeleid tot uitdrukking komen. Tevens biedt dit vak inzicht in de doelstellingen en effectiviteit van verschillende gedragsinterventies en andere mogelijkheden tot preventie van criminaliteit, met als doel voor verschillende criminaliteitsproblemen aanbevelingen te kunnen doen voor een effectieve interventie. Voorts kunnen studenten na afloop van dit vak de ontwikkelingen in het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid plaatsen in historisch kader en internationaal vergelijkend perspectief, en kunnen zij de huidige verhouding tussen dader, slachtoffers en maatschappij verklaren aan de hand van het begrip controlecultuur. Dat biedt het kader om diverse aspecten van het huidige sanctiebeleid met elkaar in verband te brengen en de maatschappelijke consequenties ervan te kunnen doorgronden.

course_title: Preventing Failed Interventions in Behavorial Research (MP05)
college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
 
Pricing and revenue management focuses on how a firm should set and update pricing and product availability decisions across its various selling channels in order to maximize its profitability. In this course you will learn to identify and exploit opportunities for revenue optimization in different business contexts and survey current practices in different industries. You will review the main methodologies that are used in each of these areas, understand key concepts including the interaction between supply and demand, opportunity costs, customer response, demand uncertainty and market segmentation. Within the broader area of pricing theory, the course places particular emphasis on tactical optimization of pricing and capacity allocation decisions, tackled using quantitative models of consumer behavior (e.g., captured via appropriate price-response relations), demand forecasts and market uncertainty, and the tools of constrained optimization – the two main building blocks of revenue optimization systems.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
 
Upon completion of this course the students will:
  • be able to identify revenue management opportunities;
  • understand the different revenue management levers and the corresponding optimization approaches;
  • understand key revenue management concepts including the interaction between supply and demand, opportunity costs, customer response, demand uncertainty and market segmentation;
  • be able to formulate and solve basic pricing and revenue management optimization problems.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
 
Price setting is a crucial aspect of a marketing strategy, involving both supply-side factors (e.g., costs) and demand-side factors (e.g., consumer willingness to pay). Pricing approaches have evolved from very restrained economic and financial perspectives to a broader consumer-oriented framework. In this course, we will study different approaches to have a comprehensive understanding of the economic, strategic, and behavioral considerations that impact a pricing strategy. We will study theoretical concepts linked to economic and behavioral approaches to pricing, value pricing, price customization/discrimination, price bundling and multi-part tariffs, dynamic pricing, retail pricing strategies, pricing for goods/services with externalities, and pricing in two-sided markets. We will use examples and case studies from various product categories such as consumer packaged goods, financial services, and cell phone plans.



  Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
 
  1. Understand the economic and financial aspects of pricing: estimate the demand curve, estimate customer willingness-to-pay, calculate profit-maximizing prices.
  2. Develop a value-based pricing strategy that also considers the effect of non-price factors on perceived value.
  3. Understand the mechanisms at play in a two-sided market, and develop pricing strategies for such markets.
  4. Learn to spot all relevant aspects of pricing in the marketplace, through business applications, examples, and case studies.

text:
Inhoud This course provides a background in the fundamental principles of ecology, including concepts of natural selection, population and community ecology, biodiversity, and sustainability. Students will acquire an "ecological literacy" about how the natural world works, and develop an understanding of how scientific methods are used to construct ecological knowledge. The course will also explore some of today's major ecological challenges, and the important research that is being done to address these concerns. As the course description suggests, ecology is aimed at giving students an overview of the field of ecology and how it applies to the sustainability of human societies. If you are curious about how the interactions between individual organisms and their environments scale up to global ecosystems, this course will provide you with a good introduction to nested complexity of the natural world.
  Leerdoelen
After completing this course, you will be able to:
  • analyse how biotic and abiotic interactions give rise to patterns of abundance and distribution of organisms at several scales;
  • design a management plan for the conservation of biodiversity in a world region by assessing the conflicts and opportunities on the use of natural resources by local populations.
  • apply ecological principles to current environmental challenges and conservation concerns;
  • characterize patterns and processes in nature through direct experience with local ecosystems;
  • assess the effects of human disturbance on ecosystems through ecological succession and alternative-stable states theory;
  • use ecological models to illustrate the abundance of organisms and the dynamics of populations over time;
  • compare structural and functional features between different types of ecosystems;

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course is designed to engage you with the key concepts, models, debates and problems in the study of business and management. The course will provide a comprehensive overview of, and critical perspective on, the key elements of the business organisation and how it interacts with its environment. After completing the course, you will have a solid understanding of how the different functional areas of management influence each other, and that, for example, a decision made by a marketing manager may affect the company’s HRM policies or performance measurement. The course will discuss managing various aspects of the business, including its 1) environment, 2) human resources, 3) strategy, 4) marketing, 5) performance measurement, and 6) information technology. Leerdoelen After the course, students are able to:
  • Understand the main theoretical perspectives on management and how they relate to the tasks, processes and content of managerial work in organizations;
  • Understand the different elements that comprise an organization and relate these to organizational structure and organizational performance;
  • Define and critically reflect on the (international) business environment;
  • Discuss theories and applications of human resource management;
  • Describe and explain the processes, tools and content involved in managing strategy;
  • Explain how marketing can add value to the business, identify the marketing environment and its stakeholders;
  • Discuss and critically reflect on generic methods of control and performance management, including financial measures to assess performance;
  • Critically reflect on how information systems, and ERP systems in particular, can transform organizations and what the antecedents for its success are;
  • Evaluate the significance of contemporary issues in business and management.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud De cursus Privaat- en ondernemingsrecht bevat een inleiding in het (privaat)recht. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan de verschillende soorten ondernemingsvormen in het eerste deel van de cursus. In het tweede deel van de cursus staat het verbintenissenrecht en vermogensrecht centraal. De voorgaande onderworpen worden getoetst door middel van een schriftelijk tentamen. Daarnaast maakt het individueel schrijven van een paper onderdeel uit van deze cursus. Het onderwerp daarvoor dient gelegen te zijn in het personen- en familierecht. De onderwerpen die in de cursus worden bestudeerd:
  • Inleiding recht (algemene begrippen)
  • Personenvennootschappen
  • Rechtspersonen (overwegend de besloten vennootschap en de naamloze vennootschap)
  • Fusies en overnames
  • Bronnen van verbintenisO
  • Overeenkomst en onrechtmatige daad als bron verbintenis
  • Niet-nakoming van verbintenissen
  • Begrippen goederenrecht en overdracht (inclusief derdenbescherming)
Leerdoelen
  • Als econoom zal de student bij het nemen van beslissingen oog moeten hebben voor de bestaande juridische problemen en de oplossingen hiervoor. Met de behandelde stof op de colleges en de te bestuderen theorie moet de student derhalve niet alleen in staat zijn het juridische probleem te beschrijven, maar moet hij tevens de relevante rechtsregels kunnen vinden, waarmee het probleem tot een oplossing kan worden gebracht. De student wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met de belangrijkste grondslagen en begrippen op het gebied van het recht. In het bijzonder wordt in deze cursus aandacht besteed aan het verbintenissenrecht, het vermogensrecht, het personen- en familierecht en het ondernemingsrecht.
  • De basisbegrippen van het recht toepassen.
  • Ten aanzien van de personenvennootschappen de noodzakelijke rechtsregels ten aanzien van oprichting, vertegenwoordiging, aansprakelijkheid en verdelingen van winsten en verliezen toepassen.
  • De voorgeschreven theorie omtrent de rechtspersonen (in het bijzonder de besloten vennootschap en naamloze vennootschap) toepassen.
  • De verschillende vormen van fusie- en overnames toepassen.
  • De bronnen van verbintenis benoemen en de samenhangende begrippen hieraan relateren.
  • Beoordelen of er een rechtsgeldige overeenkomst tot stand is gekomen, wat de inhoud daarvan is en wat de gevolgen zijn als er niet aan de noodzakelijke voorwaarden is voldaan.
  • Beoordelen of er sprake is van een onrechtmatige daad of een kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid.
  • Het leerstuk van de niet-nakoming toepassen om te beoordelen of een recht op schadevergoeding ontstaat en of ontbinding of opschorting mogelijk is.
  • De overdracht van verschillende soorten goederen (inclusief de derdenbescherming) toepassen.
  • Zijn kennis over het personen- en familierecht in een paper aantonen.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr. M de Groot', 'prof.mr. SD Lindenbergh', 'prof.mr.dr. HN Schelhaas']
text:
Inhoud In dit mastervak komen verschillende elementen uit de civielrechtelijke rechtenstudie bij elkaar. Het vak biedt mede aan de hand van actuele thema’s theoretische verdieping van het privaatrecht en bouwt tegelijkertijd voort op de vaardigheden die zijn verworven in bijvoorbeeld het mastervak Onderzoekspracticum Burgerlijk Recht (eerste blok, 15 ECTS). Wat de invalshoek betreft bouwt het vak verder voort op inzichten uit andere disciplines zoals rechtseconomie en rechtspsychologie. Inhoudelijk wordt in dit vak ook aangesloten op de onderzoekslijnen die binnen de sectie burgerlijk recht in ontwikkeling zijn. De sprekers zijn eigen docenten en ook gasten van buiten de sectie en faculteit.

LET OP: de ervaring wijst uit dat u grotere kans hebt om te slagen voor dit vak (met een hoger cijfer) als u volgens het boekje studeert en dus eerst Onderzoekspracticum volgt. De omgekeerde volgorde raden we daarom af. Leerdoelen
  • Verdiepende kennis verwerven van het privaatrecht, mede aan de hand van de actualiteit..
  • Het leren betrekken van relevante argumenten uit andere takken van de (rechts)wetenschap bij het analyseren en beoordelen van privaatrechtelijke wetgeving, literatuur, rechtspraak.
  • Het begrijpend lezen van (Engelse) teksten over privaatrecht en de multidisciplinaire benadering van het privaatrecht.
  • Het schriftelijk onder woorden kunnen brengen van argumenten uit de bestudeerde literatuur en het synthetiseren van de verschillende invalshoeken uit die literatuur tot een afgewogen standpunt met betrekking tot een opgegeven stelling.
  • Het toepassen van de bij Onderzoekspracticum Burgerlijk Recht verworven onderzoeks- en rapportagevaardigheden

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud From very humble beginnings in the 1980s, Private Equity has become a very large Asset Class. 2017 was another record year in terms of funds raised and invested into assets backed by Private Equity.
This course aims to give students a solid introduction to the world of Private Equity (including Venture Capital and Buyouts). It focuses on the following (along with practical insight from prior transactions) main areas of knowledge that underpin the PE environment:
  • “Organizational” topics related to PE funds & investing;
  • Cash flow analysis & modeling (we will be using a PE/LBO model for that);
  • Review of corporate valuation methods;
  • PE investment process (a complete cycle from a purchase idea to a completion of acquisition; and from putting the asset up for sale throughto a complete exit)- we will follow a “live” (recently completed) transaction;
  • PE transaction structuring;
  • Negotiation of a Term Sheet/Letter of Intent and Share Purchase Agreement (SPA);
  • Finalization of the transaction price (Locked Box and Completion Accounts mechanisms);
  • Practical key lessons from prior transactions, i.e. practical experience;
With the exception of item 1 (above), where some theory and “informational” delivery (deliberately kept to a modest minimum) is scheduled, this course focuses on practical aspects and transaction based learning.
  Leerdoelen
  1. Understand PE general concepts, how PE funds are formed, how they are managed and operate, how they pursue value creation for their stakeholders.
  2. Be knowledgeable about the key attributes of private equity as an asset class and main financial ratios; be able to apply specific Private Equity valuation and modelling techniques.
  3. Understand the PE process and all components needed to successfully complete a PE transaction (valuation, leverage, transaction structure, transaction due diligence SPA signing, closing and post-closing).
  4. Be able to structure private equity transactions in the context of prevailing leverage environment.
  5. Be able to understand current events or trends within the Private Equity industry and gain deeper understanding of advanced corporate finance.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. E Themeli, LL.M', 'dr. EA Ontanu', 'G Antonopoulou', 'mr. EM van Gelder', 'prof.mr.dr. XE Kramer']
text:
Inhoud Dear Students,
You have been selected to participate in this years’ PAX Moot (Private International Law Moot Court) team for the Erasmus University! Together with your teammates and coaches you are about to embark on an exciting and challenging journey towards Paris in May and, hopefully, The Hague in June.
The Pax Moot is a young international moot competition for law students. Participating in the competition is a unique opportunity for law students to enhance their research and oral skills, as well as their knowledge of private international law, arbitration and other areas of law.
The competition revolves around a fictional case. The moot problem involves a dispute relating to private international law.
This manual has been designed to provide some insight in what you can expect for the coming months. Broadly speaking we can divide the coming period in two phases, research and oral phase.
As far as the research phase is concerned, you will have to get to know the ins and outs of the distributed problem and, if necessary, ask for clarifications. These should concern the facts (not the legal issues) of the case. After all, you should start doing your research to have the line of arguments for both Claimant and Defendant ready at the beginning of April 2018. In this phase, prepare to meet with your coaches once a week for approximately 6 weeks.
The oral phase will focus on preparing you for the pleading sessions. You will get intensive coaching on your pleading skills. In addition, we will schedule meetings with professors and possibly law firms so that you will be challenged on your arguments and manner of presentation. In this phase, be prepared to meet with your coaches twice a week for approximately 6 weeks.
And then, finally, the moot in Paris and, if successful, in The Hague. The moot in Paris takes place on May 22nd and in The Hague on June 1st. Should you have any exams during or shortly before or after this period, please contact your course coordinator (Alina Ontanu or Erlis Themeli) or the professor concerned (Xandra Kramer) as they may be able to reschedule.
In the coming months a lot will be asked from you. You will be pushed to excel and this requires hard work. You are not alone in all of this, we will be there to coach, guide and support you. But never forget that we cannot decide for you which arguments to use, or what stance to take. This is your own responsibility as a team. Team spirit should and will be one of the key factors in your life during The Moot.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. W van den Heuvel', 'prof.dr.ir. R Dekker']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Many billions of dollars are invested worldwide through professional asset managers. Investment funds offered by these asset managers play an essential role in enabling individuals to invest in financial markets, for example in order to build assets for their retirement or for future educational or health care expenditures. This elective analyses the asset management industry, and addresses questions like: What is the value of active management? Are fund managers worth their fees? Do they outperform the market? How do you evaluate fund performance? What are “alpha” and “smart beta”? Do fund managers have “hot hands”? What makes hedge funds different from mutual funds? How do fund families operate? How do investors allocate their money to these funds? Is money smart? What is the role of marketing?  What incentives does a fund manager have? What is survival bias?  Do hedge funds charge fancy fees for dull results?  What is factor investing and is it worth the effort?

Apart from quantitative analyses of the asset management industry, its performance and money flows, this course also pays attention to the institutional context, and (European and US) regulations for mutual funds and alternative investment vehicles (1940 Act, UCITS, AIFMD).

  Leerdoelen After having followed this course, students have a solid analytical understanding of the mutual fund and hedge fund industries. They will be able to analyse the performance of a professional asset manager and understand what drives investors and fund managers.

course_title: Professional Development/Atelier Master IMP Part I
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This module focuses on research design. The primary goal is to enable students to design social science research in the area of international public management and policy. We will split the design process in a number of steps including research question, concept and hypothesis specification and research design. For each step we will discuss tradeoffs and relevant quality criteria, such as relevance, internal validity and external validity. This will be done through a series of lectures. Students will make a number of weekly assignments that together will cover all elements of a research proposal. Assignments will be discussed in working groups. Note that there will be one or two sessions prior to block 3, to allow you to focus your assignment on the topic of your thesis. Although most students have had a proper introduction to social science methods, they should not underestimate the difficulty of developing a relevant and rigorous research project that meets the standards of a master program. Leerdoelen After passing the module professional development students will be able:
  • to develop a relevant, feasible, and rigorous research design;
  • to indicate the trade-offs in designing research and to defend their choices made in developing their research project;
  • to evaluate research in terms of relevance, specificity, measurement reliability and measurement validity, internal validity, and external validity (generalization).

course_title: Professional Development/Atelier Master IMP Part II
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud The module Professional Development focuses on the preparation for the labor market. The program is composed of:
  • a four-days study-trip to International Organizations and Non-Governmental Organizations in Geneva. The study-trip is mandatory and involves extra costs [airfare ticket, lodging];
  • a one day visit to the European institutions in Brussels
  • a series of guest-lectures by practitioners and labor market experts to make students familiar with the and to help them to find their way at the international labor market.
The trip to Geneva takes place in the Fall, the visit to Brussels in the Spring. Students are kindly invited to participate in the design and organization of the program. Leerdoelen After passing the module professional development students will be able:
  • to describe the main features of the international labor market, including selection procedures and entrance requirements of international organizations;
  • to understand the [inter]cultural differences in work practices;
  • to write an application letter and to design a resume that meets international standards in order to be successful on the international labor market.

college: Erasmus MC Academie

Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
text:
Leerdoelen
Introduction
Academic researchers are frequently faced with dilemmas: Can I exclude particular observations from my research? Can I use exactly the same data set for multiple papers? Should I agree on a colleague being a co-author on a paper to which he/she has not made a significant contribution?
To help junior researchers address these issues, this master class will seek to raise awareness for, and where necessary help increase, scientific professionalism and integrity.
 
Aims and working method
During the first part of the master class, Professor Van Staveren and junior researchers will, in two highly interactive lectures, discuss the context of the principles, values and rules as they apply to the fields of the social sciences and the humanities research in general, and to our university in particular.
The afternoon section is reserved for the EUR Dilemma Game, which includes in-depth discussions in smaller groups on particular dilemmas. Through the game researchers are invited to exchange opinions and experiences, and defend (and possibly reconsider) alternative courses of action regarding realistic dilemmas on professionalism and integrity in research.
The 75 dilemmas included in the game have been collected through sessions at different EUR departments and institutions, and among researchers that use different research strategies and are in different stages of their careers.
 
EUR integrity declaration
According to the Erasmus University Doctoral Regulations, all academic employees and PhD candidates of Erasmus need to sign an integrity code through which they vow to comply with the principles described in The Netherlands Code of Conduct for Academic Practice (pdf). The academic integrity declaration will be signed by all participants at the end of the master class.
 
Learning objectives
The master class aims to support PhD candidates in further developing and honing their 'moral compass'. This is achieved by exposing them to academic dilemmas in the context of small group discussions and through the sharing of experiences from their own research environment.
 
Programme
09.15-09.30   welcome and introduction
09.30-10.30   interactive lecture 1
10.30-10.45   coffee and tea break
10.45-12.00   interactive lecture 2
12.00-12.30   sharing experiences from one's own research environment
12.30-13.15   lunch break
13.15-14.00   discussion on prevention: what, how, where?
14.00-15.45   exploring and discussing dilemmas in small groups
15.45-16.00   Q&A and signing the integrity declaration

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In dit vak draait het om advisering over strategische veranderingen in de organisatie, inrichting en besturing van de publieke sector. Hoewel verandering op het niveau van individuen en organisaties ook aan de orde komt, ligt de nadruk op veranderingen waar meerdere organisaties bij betrokken zijn (het interorganisatorische niveau). Het vak bouwt voort op onder meer Strategisch Management en Advisering (SMA) en Publiek Management Internationaal (PMI).

Het vak is als volgt vorm gegeven. De module omvat 7 weken. De eerste week staat in het teken van een inleidend college over achtergronden bij advisering over strategische veranderingen in de publieke sector. Vervolgens wordt wekelijks een thema aan de orde gesteld om theoretisch relevante concepten beter te doorgronden en dieper te doorleven. Daarbij valt te denken aan: de reorganisatie van de rijksdienst, gemeentelijke en provinciale samenwerking en fusies, maatschappelijk ondernemerschap en zelforganisatie in de publieke sector, verzelfstandiging van uitvoeringsorganisaties, professionalisering van toezicht, inspectie en controle, conflicthantering bij het organiseren in ketens, netwerken en allianties.

Het vak kent drie leerlijnen: conceptueel (abstract-theoretisch), experimenteel (concreet-casuïstisch) en reflexief (persoonlijk-biografisch). De onderwijsvorm is case-based en thema gericht. De opgedane kennis van de studenten wordt getoetst aan de hand van wekelijkse individuele en groepsopdrachten, gerelateerd aan een of meer cases passend bij de behandelde thema’s. Van de studenten wordt verlangd dat ze tijdens de collegedagen in groepen zelf aan het werk gaan en over de opbrengsten van dat werk terugkoppeling geven aan praktijkmensen die vooraf cases inbrengen. Leerdoelen Na afloop van de cursus kan de student:
  • strategische veranderingen van de publieke sector begrijpen, duiden en verklaren;
  • verschillende conceptuele benaderingen en strategieën van advisering over verandering onderscheiden;
  • de aangedragen theorie toepassen op actuele vraagstukken en concrete casuïstiek en deze analyseren op spanningen, dilemma’s en uitdagingen;
  • reflecteren op de theorie en de praktijk van advisering in de publieke sector;
  • professioneel adviseren over de aanpak van belangrijke veranderkundige vraagstukken in de publieke sector.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences

Leerdoelen

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. PC Bouman', 'GJJ van den Burg, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Leerdoelen:
  • In staat zijn om econometrische modellen te programmeren en hun resultaten te visualiseren in Matlab.
  • Het begrijpen van de belangrijkste verschillen tussen procedureel en objectgeoriënteerd programmeerparadigma's.
  • Het begrijpen van de basisbegrippen in objectgeoriënteerd programmeren (data hiding, interfaces, inheritance, exceptions) en in staat zijn om efficiënt te programmeren met deze begrippen in Java.
  • Het begrijpen van de 'programming by contract' aanpak en in staat zijn de kernconcepten (pre-and post-conditions) te programmeren voor een foutvrij middelgroot programma.

Inhoud:
  • Week 1-2: Intensieve inleiding programmeren met MATLAB
  • Week 3: Opfrissen Object-geörienteerd programmeren met Java
  • Week 4: Werken met interfaces
  • Week 5: Werken met inheritance
  • Week 6: Werken met datastructuren uit de Collections API
  • Week 7: Samenvatting, nieuwe technieken Java 8 en andere programmeertalen (geen tentamenstof)
Leerdoelen
  • Bekend zijn met de standaard computerarchitectuur (vonNeumann-machine) en geheugenorganisatie.
  • Het begrijpen van de belangrijkste verschillen tussen procedureel en objectgeoriënteerd programmeerparadigma's.
  • Het begrijpen van de basisbegrippen in objectgeoriënteerd programmeren (data hiding, interfaces, inheritance, exceptions, streams) en in staat zijn om efficiënt te programmeren met deze begrippen in Java.
  • Het begrijpen van de 'programming by contract' aanpak en in staat zijn de kernconcepten (pre-and post-conditions) te programmeren voor een foutvrij middelgroot programma.
  • Het begrijpen van het belang van unit testing en in staat zijn programma's te ontwerpen op een 'test-first' manier.
  • In staat zijn om econometrische modellen te programmeren en hun resultaten te visualiseren in Matlab.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course consists of practical three-hour sessions, where theory is interspersed with exercises to get hands-on experience with R. The course is graded based on the exercises that are handed in during the course. The course has a high focus on independent learning, and the students are expected to program the exercises also outside the practical sessions.
 
The course starts from the very beginning; no prior programming experience is required. Leerdoelen “The best programs are written so that computing machines can perform them quickly and so that human beings can understand them clearly.” – Donald Knuth
 
This course aims to provide you with the basic skills to write computer programs that are efficient and clearly communicated solutions. The main focus will be on programming in the field of data science, which is particularly useful for researchers, as it allows you to turn raw data into understanding, insight, and knowledge. The goal of this course is to help you learn the most important tools in the R programming language that will allow you to do data science.
 
After this course you will be able to
  • Explain the fundamentals of programming (in R)
  • Solve problems by programming them in R
  • Import, tidy, and transform data for further analysis
  • Use models and visualization to explore your data
  • Create reproducible solutions in R that can be used by others

course_title: Programming for Data Science and Marketing Analytics
college: Erasmus School of Economics
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AAM Abdelwahed, MBA', 'dr. Y Ghiassi-Farrokhfal', 'R Matheus']
text:
Inhoud Course Description
 
This course aims to strengthen your abilities as future managers with one of the most important yet mostly missing skills for managers: the art of programming. Managers with programming experience are able to be involved in the decision-making process of their developers. They can also --at high level-- understand whether or not each developer is performing well. In this course, we will focus on one of the most widely used programming languages: Java. This course also lays the foundation for learning other important programming languages. You should not expect to be developers in few weeks. You should rather treat this course as an intense programming tutorial for absolute beginners. It is assumed that the registered students have no previous knowledge of programming. After taking this course, you will learn how to excel in Java even further or to start learning a new programming language from scratch. Java is greatly structured to be an easy-to-learn, yet a powerful programming language.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
 
The main objective of this course is to develop comprehensive knowledge about the fundamental principles and concepts of modern computer programming. In this course, the students will gain a broad understanding of problem analysis, solution design, coding and debugging of computer programs. In particular, upon completion of the course, it is expected that you will be able to:
  • Translate well specified problems into pseudo-code solutions and then code them in Java
  • Write small programs that allow you to accomplish useful goals
  • Understand the fundamentals of the syntax and semantics of Java programming language.
  • Define the necessary program structure in terms of the basic building blocks (classes, methods and properties)

course_title: Project Development: Analysing Visual Cultural Representations
college: Erasmus University College
lecturers: ['dr. R van den Akker', 'T de Groot, MPhil']
text:
Inhoud During this course you will combine the skills you have gained over the past the year to undertake a research project from start to finish. You will familiarize yourself with a new qualitative research method: ethnography (predominantly participant observation). Because you will have the entire Quad to predominantly focus on your research, you will be able to go in depth and do extensive field research. The research project serves as a practice-run for the capstone you will write in your third year.
 
The only way to successfully complete the project is to work together as a team. The importance of teamwork is often underestimated, and creating a strong team in which all team members are able to live up to their full potential is not an easy task. By doing some teamwork exercises and meeting regularly with your tutor to discuss your progress, we provide you with the opportunity to practice working in a larger team where you will have to solve any teamwork issues you might encounter.
Leerdoelen After completing this course, you will:
  • Have improved your teamwork skills;
  • Have had some more practice in undertaking extensive research in a topic of your choosing;
  • Have had practice in gathering data according to the qualitative research method ethnography (predominantly participant observation);
  • Have improved your general writing and presentation skills.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In order to get prepared to be real cultural entrepreneurs for the labor market the course is divided in three parts:

(1) Conceptual Development: development of a business plan;
(2) Realization: effectuation of the project; and
(3) Reporting and Evaluation: beyond realization, students will write a critical essay discussing “what happened?", “what I would have done differently?", and “what I learned from this experience?”.

The requirements for this seminar are basic knowledge about culture in general (performing or visual arts), and entrepreneurship.
  Leerdoelen The aim of this seminar is to learn from real life entrepeneurial experiences. Master students will realize an artistic production, a consultancy report or a case study with entrepreneurial aspects within three months. They will act as junior agents, performing as programmers, economists, planners, managers, marketers, auditors, fundraisers, etc. in an entrepreneurial way (with innovative elements) and with a holistic approach. They will develop competencies such as creative and critical thinking, practical (group) working skills, coordinating, collaboration, self-reflection, critical controlling, independent decision making, and performing under stress.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. RA Uittenbogaard', 'mr. AA Pasaribu', 'mr. CFE Sullivan', 'mr. HY Wu', 'mr. ME de Ruijter - Nobel', 'mr. RJ Theissen', 'mr. SRMC Vogelsang', 'mr.dr. JGCM Galle', 'mr.drs. DC Oosthoek', 'prof.dr. KWH Broekhuizen', 'prof.mr. HM Vletter - van Dort', 'RK Pijpers']
text:
Inhoud In dit vak wordt vanuit verschillende perspectieven ingegaan op de wijze waarop wordt getracht de financiële soliditeit van het financiële systeem als geheel (macroprudentieel toezicht) en van individuele financiële ondernemingen en financiële groepen (microprudentieel toezicht) te waarborgen. Daarbij wordt zowel aandacht besteed aan wet- en regelgeving als aan toezicht en handhaving. Ook de historische ontwikkeling van financiële regulering en toezicht en de samenhang in het toezicht worden besproken.

De prudentiële eisen waaraan financiële ondernemingen en financiële groepen moeten voldoen, vormen het hoofdonderwerp van dit vak. Dit betreft markttoegang, kapitaaleisen, maar ook de eisen die in het kader van een adequate governance worden gesteld aan de wijze waarop bestuur en toezicht zijn vormgegeven en de bedrijfsvoering is ingericht.
Verder zal er aandacht zijn voor systeemtoezicht, toezicht op gedrag en cultuur en de wet- en regelgeving en het toezichtinstrumentarium voor het geval een financiële onderneming in financiële problemen komt en moet worden afgewikkeld en de rol en opzet van garantiestelsels.

Regelmatig zullen gastdocenten college geven om inzichten uit de praktijk in te brengen. Ook zal er veel gebruik worden gemaakt van casusposities. Van studenten wordt een actieve inbreng verwacht.
 
Wijzigingen in het vak naar aanleiding van onderwijsevaluaties:

Er zal meer aansluiting worden gezocht tussen hoor- en werkcolleges.
In het vak zal een tweede grote casus worden toegevoegd waarin multidisciplinaire aanpak, samenwerking over een complex reguleringsvraagstuk vereist wordt.
Teneinde het vak goed te laten aansluiten op het vak Financiële markten en toezicht in blok 2 en de studenten nog vertrouwder te maken met de juridische basis van de prudentiële vereisten en het toezicht daarop, zal in de werkcolleges een aantal juridische praktijkvragen worden bestudeerd. Deze werkcolleges zullen worden verzorgd aan de hand van vooraf te bestuderen opgaven. Leerdoelen In het vak Prudentieel toezicht & governance wordt ingegaan op het prudentiële toezicht op de financiële sector in den brede, dat wil zeggen dat niet alleen aan banken, maar ook aan verzekeraars en aan het betalingsverkeer aandacht wordt besteed. Het vak zoekt daarmee verbreding, maar beoogt ook verdieping in de vorm van analyse van de rol van diverse toezichthouders, nationaal en internationaal, en uitwerking van casusposities.

Belangrijke onderdelen van het vak vormen de ontwikkelingen op Europees niveau, zoals de totstandkoming van de Bankenunie, de steeds verdergaande harmonisatie van wet- en regelgeving en het toenemende belang van een adequate corporate governance. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan technologische ontwikkelingen binnen de financiële sector en de gevolgen daarvan voor wat betreft markttoegang en prudentieel toezicht.

In werkcolleges worden door middel van groepsopdrachten op multidisciplinaire wijze casussen behandeld. Na afronding van dit vak bent u door bestudering van de literatuur, het volgen van de colleges, het maken van discussieopdrachten, het schrijven van een probleemstelling en het uitwerken van een aantal casusposities in staat om de verschillende aspecten van de prudentiële eisen te doorgronden en te beoordelen.
  1. U kunt de belangrijkste economische redenen en de politiek-maatschappelijke motieven voor de prudentiële regulering van en het prudentiële toezicht op financiële markten en hun actoren, alsmede in de historische ontwikkeling daarvan, in eigen woorden beschrijven.
  2. U kent de redenen voor en de inhoud en structuur van de belangrijkste prudentiële regelgeving met betrekking tot banken, verzekeraars en betaalinstellingen. U kunt deze kennis toepassen in het analyseren van concrete casussen. U kunt de prudentiele regels voor banken en verzekeraars vergelijken en overeenkomsten en verschillen benoemen en toelichten.
  3. U kunt in de belangrijkste Europese en nationale rechtsbronnen van en toezichtstructuren omtrent prudentieel toezicht uw weg vinden en u bent in staat deze toe te passen in concrete casussen.
  4. U kunt een beargumenteerd oordeel geven van uitingen van (inter)nationale instituties die een rol spelen in het toezicht op de financiële sector en discussies daarover in de literatuur en media duiden.

Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud The different psychological assessment instruments are important tools to gather information from clients in order to ‘diagnose’ clients and to provide recommendations that have the highest likelyhood of success. Psychodiagnostic tools enhance diagnostic accuracy derived from the anamnestic interview because the instruments are (more or less) valid and reliable. This course deals with both the psychodiagnostic theories as well as the application of the psychodiagnostic tools. The different steps in the diagnostic process are always in interaction with a client and therefore, a requirement of this course is the course 'Clinical Communciation Skills'.
  Leerdoelen As has been said this course is an introduction to world of Psycho-diagnostics. After completing the course Psycho-diagnostics and Anamnesis you will have acquired:
  • Basic knowledge of how a professional consultation is conducted following the hypothesis-testing model
  • Basic knowledge of personality testing, intelligence testing, neuropsychological testing and anamnesis
  • Skills in administering, scoring and interpreting some commonly used tests
  • Basic skills in anamnestic interviewing
  • Basic skills in making a DSM-V diagnosis based on an anamnestic interview and observation data
  • An experience in writing a test report based on diagnostic test data
  • An experience in providing feedback to a client about his/her test results based on a test report

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This elective is aimed at psychology students who would like to learn more about psychology as a science. In this course you will learn how psychological questions can be investigated in a methodologically sound way and how scientific literature can be evaluated. Students learn step-by-step how to get from research question to data collection: which research designs are possible, how to avoid confounds and other interfering factors, which conclusions can and cannot be drawn from data and how to write up research in a clear and scientific way. As part of this course a small experiment will be conducted with the Implicit Association Test, which is often used to investigate stereotyping. Literature on this topic will be used to illustrate research design and the results of the experiment will be the basis of a research report. The structure and content of a research report will be discussed in several tutorial meetings. During practical meetings students will practice with Excel and SPSS and learn how to analyse data and create scientific quality graphs. The statistics covered in this course will overlap with BA1 and BA2, but students will get a deeper and more critical understanding of these topics. At the end of the course students can design, execute, analyze, and report scientific research. In addition, they will be able to critically read scientific articles. The grade for the course will be a combination of the grades for the theoretical exam, practical (open book) exam and the written reports. This elective connects to a special bachelor thesis track in which students perform their own research (under supervision) that will be written up in their bachelor’s thesis.  Leerdoelen Why do you forget someone’s name? Why do people who are in love get butterflies in their stomach? Are boys better in math than girls? Do you really use only 10% of your brain? Psychologists try to answer such questions, but they do not always agree. How do we distinguish chitchat from fact? And how do we acquire those facts?
In this elective students will attend lectures, tutorial group meetings and practicals to learn skills that are needed to understand and conduct scientific studies. They will conduct a small experiment on stereotyping and practice analyzing the results and writing a scientific report of this experiment.
During this course students can also start a supervised research project that will serve as the basis for their bachelor’s thesis. The research project will continue to run parallel to course periods 4 to 6. This special track of the bachelor’s thesis is not mandatory, but highly recommended for students who take this elective.
 
By the end of this course students will be able to:
 
  • Understand experimental and other research designs
  • Set up a simple experiment
  • Collect data
  • Test hypotheses
  • Interpret the results
  • Critically read scientific articles
  • Write a research report
  • Create graphs
  • Find relevant literature

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Door middel van het blok Psychologie van de opleiding Criminologie wordt een inleiding op verschillende perspectieven en thema’s binnen de psychologie gegeven. Daarbij ligt de nadruk op die perspectieven en thema’s die bij uitstek relevant zijn voor de criminologie. Bij de behandeling van deze onderwerpen wordt verwezen naar concrete maatschappelijke problemen en toepassingen in onderzoek. Er wordt in het blok bijvoorbeeld aandacht besteed aan de vraag: hoe kan antisociaal of crimineel gedrag worden verklaard aan de hand van psychologische mechanismen? Daarnaast wordt bekeken hoe psychologische mechanismen andere fenomenen uit de criminologie kunnen verklaren. Leerdoelen Na succesvolle afronding van het blok kun je:
  1. Belangrijke begrippen uit de psychologie en haar stromingen en bijbehorende klassieke onderzoeken omschrijven en uitleggen;
  2. Antisociaal gedrag, inclusief criminaliteit, verklaren met behulp van psychologische theorieën;
  3. Criminaliteit gerelateerde onderwerpen en reacties duiden en evalueren met behulp van kennis over de psychologie. 
Na succesvolle afronding van het practicum kun je:
  1. Zelfstandig variabelen construeren en de data beschrijven met behulp van SPSS;
  2. Zelfstandig de samenhang tussen twee variabelen analyseren met behulp van de juiste toetsen in SPSS;
  3. Tabellen maken om resultaten overzichtelijk te presenteren en deze juist interpreteren.
  4. Op wetenschappelijke wijze een methode- en resultatenparagraaf schrijven met betrekking tot vragenlijstonderzoek.
